Market surveillance of products — ensuring compliance with EU legislation
Market surveillance of products — ensuring compliance with EU legislation
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 — on market surveillance and compliance of products and amending Directive 2004/42/EC and Regulations (EC) No 765/2008 and (EU) No 305/2011
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to ensure that products placed on the EU market comply with EU legislation on health and safety, consumer protection, environmental protection, public security and other public interests.
It replaces the market surveillance framework established by Regulation (EC) No 765/2008.
KEY POINTS
The scope of the regulation is limited to products covered by EU harmonisation legislation listed in Annex I (manufactured products other than food, feed, medicinal products for human and veterinary use, living plants and animals, products of human origin and products of plants and animals relating directly to their future reproduction).
The regulation does not apply to products covered by specific provisions in EU harmonisation legislation.
It applies to economic operators (manufacturers, importers or authorised representatives) who place products on the market.
The regulation sets out the powers of the competent authorities of the EU countries in order to ensure compliance of products with EU legislation and to protect the health and safety of consumers and other end users.
The regulation also sets out the powers of the competent authorities of the EU countries in relation to controls on products entering the customs territory of the Union.
EU countries are required to designate their own market surveillance authorities and appoint a single liaison office for cooperation between those authorities and the Commission.
The Commission may designate testing facilities as Union testing facilities.
The regulation sets out the powers of the competent authorities of the EU countries in order to ensure compliance of products with EU legislation and to protect the health and safety of consumers and other end users.
The regulation also sets out the powers of the competent authorities of the EU countries in relation to controls on products entering the customs territory of the Union.
EU countries are required to designate their own market surveillance authorities and appoint a single liaison office for cooperation between those authorities and the Commission.
The Commission may designate testing facilities as Union testing facilities.
The regulation sets up the Union Product Compliance Network (the ‘Network’), hosted by the Commission, aimed at structured coordination and cooperation between enforcement authorities of the EU countries and the Commission.
The Network aims to facilitate the implementation of joint enforcement activities by EU countries, such as joint investigations.
The Network involves the authorities of the EU countries, the Commission, and the European Commission’s Joint Research Centre.
The Network also involves the competent authorities in charge of the control on products entering the customs territory of the Union.
The Network is composed of 2 coordination groups: the technical working group and the steering group.
The technical working group is chaired by the Commission and the steering group is chaired by the European Commission’s Joint Research Centre.
The regulation also establishes a peer review system for market surveillance authorities.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 16 July 2019.

Summary 2:
Online transmission of TV programmes and retransmission of TV programmes
Online transmission of TV programmes and retransmission of TV programmes
SUMMARY OF:
Directive (EU) 2019/789 – laying down rules on the exercise of copyright and related rights applicable to certain online transmissions of broadcasting organisations and retransmissions of television and radio programmes, and amending Council Directive 93/83/EEC
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE?
              
It aims to enhance access to a greater number of television and radio programmes across the EU by facilitating the clearance of rights for the provision of online services that are ancillary to the broadcast of certain types of television and radio programmes, and for the retransmission of television and radio programmes.
KEY POINTS
The directive lays down rules that aim to enhance cross-border access to a greater number of television and radio programmes, by facilitating the clearance of rights for the provision of online services that are ancillary to the broadcast of certain types of television and radio programmes, and for the retransmission of television and radio programmes.
The directive applies to:
ancillary online services, which consist in the provision to the public of television or radio programmes simultaneously with or for a defined period of time after their broadcast by the broadcasting organisation, as well as of any material which is ancillary to such broadcast;
retransmissions of television or radio programmes originating in another EU country.
The directive provides for a mandatory collective management of rights for certain types of programmes for retransmission services and for the transmission of programmes through the process of direct injection.
The directive does not oblige broadcasting organisations to provide such services across borders or operators of retransmission services to include in their services television or radio programmes originating in other EU countries.
The directive does not oblige broadcasters to provide such services across borders or operators of retransmission services to include in their services television or radio programmes originating in other EU countries.
The acts of communication to the public of works or other protected subject matter, by wire or wireless means, and of making available to the public of works or other protected subject matter, by wire or wireless means, in such a way that members of the public may access them from a place and at a time individually chosen by them, occurring when providing to the public:
radio programmes;
television programmes which are:
news and current affairs programmes; or
fully financed own productions of the broadcasting organisation,
in an ancillary online service by or under the control and responsibility of a broadcasting organisation, as well as the acts of reproduction of such works or other protected subject matter which are necessary for the provision of, the access to or the use of such online service for the same programmes shall, for the purposes of exercising copyright and related rights relevant for those acts, be deemed to occur solely in the Member State in which the broadcasting organisation has its principal establishment.
Point (b) of the first subparagraph shall not apply to the broadcasts of sports events and works and other protected subject matter included in them.
Member States shall ensure that rightholders may exercise their right to grant or refuse the authorisation for a retransmission only through a collective management organisation.
Where a rightholder has not transferred the management of the right referred to in the second subparagraph of paragraph 1 to a collective management organisation, the collective management organisation which manages rights of the same category for the territory of the Member State for which the operator of a retransmission service seeks to clear rights for a retransmission shall be deemed to have the right to grant or refuse the authorisation for a retransmission for that rightholder.
However, where more than one collective management organisation manages rights of that category for the territory of that Member State, it shall be for the Member State for the territory of which the operator of a retransmission service seeks to clear rights for a retransmission to decide which collective management organisation or organisations have the right to grant or refuse the authorisation for a retransmission.
Member States shall ensure that a rightholder has the same rights and obligations resulting from an agreement between an operator of a retransmission service and a collective management organisation or organisations that act pursuant to paragraph 2, as rightholders who have mandated that collective management organisation or organisations. Member States shall also ensure that that rightholder is able to claim those rights within a period, to be fixed by the Member State concerned, which shall not be shorter than three years from the date of the retransmission which includes his or her work or other protected subject matter.
Member States shall ensure that Article 4 does not apply to the rights in retransmission exercised by a broadcasting organisation in respect of its own transmission, irrespective of whether the rights concerned are its own or have been transferred to it by other rightholders.
Member States shall provide that, where broadcasting organisations and the operators of retransmission services enter into negotiations regarding authorisation for retransmission under this Directive, those negotiations are to be conducted in good faith.
Member States shall ensure that it is possible to call upon the assistance of one or more mediators as provided for in Article 11 of Directive 93/83/EEC where no agreement is concluded between the collective management organisation and the operator of a retransmission service, or between the operator of a retransmission service and the broadcasting organisation regarding authorisation for retransmission of broadcasts.
Member States may provide that the rules in this Chapter and in Chapter III of Directive 93/83/EEC apply to situations where both the initial transmission and the retransmission take place within their territory.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY?
              
It applies from 10 July 2020.

Summary 3:
Top-level domain.eu
Top-level domain.eu
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the conditions for the implementation of the top-level domain.eu and its variants in other scripts. It also lays down the conditions for the designation and characteristics of the registry, which is responsible for the organisation, administration and management of the.eu top-level domain (TLD).
KEY POINTS
The.eu TLD provides a clearly identifiable link with the European Union and the European market place. It enables undertakings, organisations and natural persons within the European Union to register a domain name under the.eu TLD.
The registry must comply with the principles of non-discrimination and transparency, and must implement measures to safeguard fair competition that are authorised in advance by the Commission, in particular when the registry provides services to undertakings with whom it competes on downstream markets.
The registry must promote the objectives of the European Union in the field of internet governance, inter alia by participating in international forums.
The registry must designate a competent authority to enable competent authorities to have access to data in the registry for the purposes of prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of crime, as provided by Union law or national law that complies with Union law.
The registry must ensure the availability and integrity of the databases of domain names.
The registry must be a not-for-profit organisation and have its registered office, central administration and principal place of business within the territory of the European Union.
The Commission shall monitor and supervise the organisation, administration and management of the.eu TLD by the registry.
The Commission shall designate an entity as the registry following the completion of the procedure established in this regulation.
The registry must be required to:
promote the.eu TLD across the European Union and in third countries;
comply with the rules, policies and procedures laid down in this regulation, with the contract concluded between the Commission and the registry, and, in particular, with Union data protection law;
organise, administer and manage the.eu TLD in the general public interest and ensure in all aspects of the administration and management of the.eu TLD, high quality, transparency, security, stability, predictability, reliability, accessibility, efficiency, non-discrimination, fair conditions of competition and consumer protection;
enter into an appropriate contract providing for the delegation of the.eu TLD code, subject to the prior consent of the Commission;
perform the registration of domain names in the.eu TLD where requested by any eligible party referred to in Article 3;
ensure, without prejudice to any court proceedings, and subject to adequate procedural guarantees for the parties concerned, the possibility for registrars and registrants to resolve any contractual dispute with the registry by means of alternative dispute resolution;
ensure the availability and integrity of the databases of domain names;
at its own expense and with the consent of the Commission, enter into an agreement with a reputable trustee or other escrow agent established within the territory of the European Union designating the Commission as the beneficiary of the escrow agreement, and submit an up-to-date electronic copy of the content of the.eu TLD database to the respective trustee or escrow agent on a daily basis;
promote the objectives of the European Union in the field of internet governance, inter alia by participating in international forums;
publish the principles and procedures on the functioning of the.eu TLD laid down on the basis of Article 11 in all of the official languages of the European Union institutions;
at its own expense, undertake an audit by an independent body at least every two years to certify its compliance with this regulation and send the outcome of such audits to the Commission;
participate, where requested by the Commission, in the work of the.eu Multistakeholder Advisory Group and cooperate with the Commission to improve the functioning and management of the.eu TLD.
The registry must impose fees which shall be directly related to the costs incurred.
The Commission shall designate an entity as the registry following the completion of the procedure established in this regulation.
The Commission shall enter into a contract with the designated registry. The contract shall specify the rules, policies and procedures for the provision of services by the registry and the conditions according to which the Commission is to supervise the organisation, administration and management of the.eu TLD by the registry.
The Commission shall adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 18 to supplement this regulation by establishing the eligibility and selection criteria and the procedure for the designation of the registry.
The Commission shall set out the principles to be included in the contract between the Commission and the registry, by means of implementing acts.
The Commission shall designate an entity as the registry following the completion of the procedure established in this regulation.
The Commission shall enter into a contract with the designated registry. The contract shall specify the rules, policies and procedures for the provision of services by the registry and the conditions according to which the Commission is to supervise the organisation, administration and management of the.eu TLD by the registry.
The Commission shall adopt implementing acts in accordance with Article 17(3) to designate the registry by way of derogation from paragraphs 1, 2 and 3.
The Commission shall adopt implementing acts in accordance with Article 17(2) to set out the principles to be included in the contract between the Commission and the registry.
The Commission shall adopt implementing acts in accordance with Article 17(2) to set out the principles and procedures concerning the functioning of the.eu TLD, in compliance with this regulation, including the following:
an alternative dispute resolution policy;
requirements and procedures for registration requests, a policy on the verification of registration criteria, a policy on the verification of registrants' data, and a policy on the speculative registration of domain names;
a policy on abusive registration of domain names and a policy on the timely identification of domain names that have been registered and used in bad faith, referred to in Article 4;
a policy on the revocation of domain names;
the treatment of intellectual property rights;
measures to enable competent authorities to have access to data in the registry for the purposes of prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of crime, as provided by Union law or national law that complies with Union law, subject to appropriate checks and balances;
detailed procedures by means of which to amend the contract.
The registry shall be a not-for-profit organisation. It shall have its registered office, central administration and principal place of business within the territory of the European Union.
The Commission shall designate an entity as the registry following the completion of the procedure established in this regulation.
The Commission shall enter into a contract with the designated registry. The contract shall specify the rules, policies and procedures for the provision of services by the registry and the conditions according to which the Commission is to supervise the organisation, administration and management of the.eu TLD by the registry.
The Commission shall adopt implementing acts in accordance with Article 17(3) to designate the registry by way of derogation from paragraphs 1, 2 and 3.
The Commission shall adopt implementing acts in accordance with Article 17(2) to set out the principles to be included in the contract between the Commission and the registry.
The Commission shall adopt implementing acts in accordance with Article 17(2) to set out the principles and procedures concerning the functioning of the.eu TLD, in compliance with this regulation, including the following:
an alternative dispute



Summary 4:
Connecting Europe Facility (CEF)
The Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) is the EU's main financial instrument for the development of EU trans-European networks (TENs) in the fields of transport, energy and digital infrastructure. It is a key instrument in the EU's long-term strategy to achieve smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and to stimulate job creation. It supports the European Green Deal, the EU's ambitious long-term vision for a fair, prosperous, democratic and sustainable future. It also supports the EU's climate change mitigation and adaptation objectives.
CEF and the European Green Deal
CEF supports the EU's long-term vision for a fair, prosperous, democratic and sustainable future for all. It supports the European Green Deal, the EU's ambitious long-term vision for a fair, prosperous, democratic and sustainable future.
CEF supports the European Green Deal in the following ways:
by supporting the development of a clean, affordable and secure energy system through the modernisation of the energy sector and the development of renewable energy;
by supporting the development of a smart and efficient energy system through the development of smart grids and innovative storage solutions;
by supporting the development of a low-emission mobility system through the development of clean and efficient transport systems, the development of clean urban transport systems and the development of sustainable alternative fuels;
by supporting the development of a circular economy through the development of new and innovative materials and the development of new waste management systems.

Summary 5:
Addressing the dissemination of terrorist content online
Addressing the dissemination of terrorist content online
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2021/784 on addressing the dissemination of terrorist content online
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to ensure the smooth functioning of the digital single market in an open and democratic society by addressing the misuse of hosting services for terrorist purposes and contributing to public security across the Union.
It establishes a definition of ‘terrorist content’ for preventative purposes and provides for specific measures to address the dissemination of terrorist content online.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to providers of information society services that store and disseminate to the public information and material provided by a user of the service on request, irrespective of whether the storing and dissemination to the public of such information and material is of a mere technical, automatic and passive nature.
The regulation does not apply to providers of ‘mere conduit’ or ‘caching’ services, as well as to providers of domain name systems (DNS), payment or distributed denial of service (DdoS) protection services.
Definition of terrorist content
The regulation defines ‘terrorist content’ as material that incites or solicits someone to commit, or to contribute to the commission of, terrorist offences, solicits someone to participate in activities of a terrorist group, or glorifies terrorist activities including by disseminating material depicting a terrorist attack.
It also includes material that provides instruction on the making or use of explosives, firearms or other weapons or noxious or hazardous substances, as well as chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear (CBRN) substances, or on other specific methods or techniques, including the selection of targets, for the purpose of committing or contributing to the commission of terrorist offences.
When assessing whether material constitutes terrorist content within the meaning of this regulation, competent authorities and hosting service providers take into account factors such as the nature and wording of statements, the context in which the statements were made and their potential to lead to harmful consequences in respect of the security and safety of persons.
The fact that the material was produced by, is attributable to or is disseminated on behalf of a person, group or entity included in the Union list of persons, groups and entities involved in terrorist acts and subject to restrictive measures constitutes an important factor in the assessment.
Specific measures
The regulation provides for a number of specific measures to address the dissemination of terrorist content online, including:
a requirement to preserve the removed content and related data for a period of 6 months in order to allow content providers sufficient time to initiate administrative or judicial review proceedings and to enable access by law enforcement authorities to relevant data for the investigation and prosecution of terrorist offences;
a requirement to establish user-friendly complaint mechanisms and ensure that complaints are dealt with expeditiously and in full transparency towards the content provider;
a requirement to publish annual transparency reports containing information about action taken in relation to the identification and removal of terrorist content;
a requirement to put in place specific measures taking into account the risks and level of exposure to terrorist content as well as the effects on the rights of third parties and the public interest to information.
Competent authorities
The regulation requires the designation of competent authorities by the Member States. The competent authorities fulfil their tasks in an objective and non-discriminatory manner and do not seek or take instructions from any other body in relation to the exercise of the tasks under this regulation.
The Commission publishes a register listing the competent authorities designated under this regulation.
Removal orders
The regulation provides for a procedure and obligations resulting from removal orders requiring hosting service providers to remove or disable access to terrorist content, following an assessment by the competent authorities.
The competent authority submits the removal order directly to the contact point designated or established by the hosting service provider for the purposes of this regulation by any electronic means capable of producing a written record under conditions that allow the hosting service provider to establish the authenticity of the order, including the accuracy of the date and the time of sending and receipt thereof.
The competent authority should provide the hosting service provider with information on procedures and applicable deadlines at least 12 hours in advance of issuing for the first time a removal order to that hosting service provider.
Where the hosting service provider cannot comply with the removal order within one hour of its receipt, on grounds of force majeure or de facto impossibility, including for objectively justifiable technical or operational reasons, it should inform the issuing competent authority as soon as possible and comply with the removal order as soon as the situation is resolved.
The removal order should contain a statement of reasons qualifying the material to be removed or access to which is to be disabled as terrorist content and provide sufficient information for the location of that content, by indicating the exact URL and, where necessary, any other additional information, such as a screenshot of the content in question.
The competent authority should submit the removal order directly to the contact point designated or established by the hosting service provider for the purposes of this regulation by any electronic means capable of producing a written record under conditions that allow the hosting service provider to establish the authenticity of the order, including the accuracy of the date and the time of sending and receipt thereof, such as by secured email or platforms or other secured channels, including those made available by the hosting service provider, in accordance with Union law on the protection of personal data.
It should be possible for the competent authority of the Member State where the hosting service provider has its main establishment or where its legal representative resides or is established to scrutinise the removal order issued by competent authorities of another Member State to determine whether it seriously or manifestly infringes this regulation or the fundamental rights enshrined in the Charter.
Penalties
The regulation provides for the possibility for the competent authorities to impose penalties on hosting service providers that fail to comply with the requirements of this regulation. The penalties may include fines and/or other penalties, such as the suspension or revocation of licences or authorisations.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 7 July 2021.

Summary 6:
Regulation (EU) 2021/695 — the Horizon Europe Programme for research and innovation
Regulation (EU) 2021/695 — the Horizon Europe Programme for research and innovation
The Horizon Europe Programme is the new EU framework programme for research and innovation (R&I) for the period 2021-2027. It replaces the Horizon 2020 Programme, which ran from 2014 to 2020.
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes the Horizon Europe Programme for 7 years from 2021 to 2027.
KEY POINTS
The Horizon Europe Programme aims to:
strengthen the European Research Area (ERA) by improving the circulation of researchers and knowledge;
deliver on the EU’s strategic priorities and commitments;
support the EU’s values and the well-being of its citizens;
deliver scientific, technological, economic, environmental and societal impact in pursuit of these objectives.
The Programme will support the creation, better diffusion and transfer of high-quality and excellent knowledge and high-quality technologies in the EU, attract talent at all levels and contribute to full engagement of the EU’s talent pool, facilitate collaborative links and strengthen the impact of R&I in developing, supporting and implementing EU policies, support and strengthen the uptake and deployment of innovative and sustainable solutions in the EU’s economy, in particular in SMEs, and in society, address global challenges, including climate change and the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), create jobs, boost economic growth, promote industrial competitiveness and boost the attractiveness of the EU in the field of R&I.
The Programme fosters all forms of innovation, including breakthrough innovation, fosters market deployment of innovative solutions, and optimises the delivery of such investment for increased impact within a strengthened ERA.
The Programme will contribute to increasing public and private investment in R&I in the EU, thereby helping to reach an overall investment target of at least 3 % of the EU’s gross domestic product (GDP) in research and development. Achieving that target would require EU countries and the private sector to complement the Programme with their own reinforced investment actions in research, development and innovation.
The Programme will benefit from complementarity with existing relevant European R&I roadmaps and strategies, as well as with important projects of common European interest (IPCEIs), where relevant, provided that related R&I needs are identified in the Programme’s strategic planning.
The Programme supports R&I activities in the field of social sciences and humanities (SSH). This entails advancing scientific knowledge in that domain and making use of insights and progress from SSH to increase the economic and societal impact of the Programme. Under the pillar ‘Global Challenges and European Industrial Competitiveness’, SSH should be fully integrated across all clusters.
The Programme will support the EU’s industry in remaining or in becoming a world leader in innovation, digitisation and climate neutrality, in particular through investments in key enabling technologies that will underpin tomorrow’s business.
The Programme will support R&I in an integrated manner, respecting all relevant provisions in the framework of the World Trade Organization. The concept of research, including experimental development, should be used in accordance with the Frascati Manual developed by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), whereas the concept of innovation should be used in accordance with the Oslo Manual developed by the OECD and Eurostat, which follows a broad approach that covers social innovation and design. As in Horizon 2020, the OECD definitions regarding technological readiness levels (TRLs) should continue to be taken into account in the classification of technological research, product development and demonstration activities, and in the definition of types of action available in calls for proposals. Grants should not be awarded for actions where activities go above TRL 8. It should be possible for the work programme to allow grants for large-scale product validation and market replication for a given call under the pillar ‘Global Challenges and European Industrial Competitiveness’.

Summary 7:
The EU Space Programme
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2021/696 establishing the Union Space Programme and the European Union Agency for the Space Programme and repealing Regulations (EU) No 912/2010, (EU) No 1285/2013 and (EU) No 377/2014 and Decision No 541/2014/EU
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes the Union Space Programme (the Programme) and the European Union Agency for the Space Programme (the Agency).
It repeals Regulations (EU) No 912/2010, (EU) No 1285/2013 and (EU) No 377/2014, which established the European GNSS Agency, the Copernicus Programme and the European Defence Fund respectively, and Decision No 541/2014/EU, which established the European Union Satellite Centre.
KEY POINTS
              
The Programme
The Programme aims to ensure the competitiveness of the Union’s space industry and to promote the use of space data, information and services across the Union and beyond.
It covers 3 main areas:
access to space: it aims to ensure the Union’s access to space and its security in space, and to support the development of the space ground infrastructure and launch systems;
support to the space industry: it aims to ensure the competitiveness of the Union’s space industry and to support the development of the space sector;
downstream applications: it aims to support the development of space-enabled applications and services.
The Programme covers 4 main components:
Galileo: it aims to ensure the full operational capability of the Galileo system and to support the development of downstream applications based on Galileo services;
EGNOS: it aims to ensure the full operational capability of the EGNOS system and to support the development of downstream applications based on EGNOS services;
Copernicus: it aims to ensure the full operational capability of the Copernicus system and to support the development of downstream applications based on Copernicus services;
Space Surveillance and Tracking (SST): it aims to ensure the full operational capability of the SST system and to support the development of downstream applications based on SST services.
The Agency
The Agency is a European Union agency. Its mission is to contribute to the Programme, particularly as regards security accreditation as well as market and downstream applications development.
The Agency is responsible for the security accreditation tasks for all the Union actions in the space sector.
It is also responsible for user-uptake activities relating to the Programme’s components other than Galileo and EGNOS, as well as downstream application development activities for all the Programme’s components.
The Agency performs the tasks which the Commission confers on it by means of one or more contribution agreements under an FFPA covering other specific tasks associated with the Programme.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 July 2021.

Summary 8:
Digital Europe Programme
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2021/694 establishing the Digital Europe Programme and repealing Decision (EU) 2015/2240
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
              
It establishes the Digital Europe Programme (DEP) for the period 2021-202Y. The DEP is a key component of the European Digital Strategy, which aims to transform and modernise European industry, public services and public administration.
KEY POINTS
              
The DEP has 5 specific objectives, which are:
high-performance computing (HPC) (1);
artificial intelligence (AI);
cybersecurity and trust;
advanced digital skills;
deployment and best use of digital capacities and interoperability.
The DEP supports the digital transformation of industry and the wider use of essential digital capacities, in particular in the fields of HPC, AI, cybersecurity and trust, and advanced digital skills.
The DEP is implemented through projects that reinforce and widen the use of essential digital capacities, such as HPC, AI and cybersecurity, and through European Digital Innovation Hubs (EDIHs).
European Digital Innovation Hubs
The DEP establishes a network of European Digital Innovation Hubs (EDIHs), which act as access points for the latest digital capacities, including HPC, AI, cybersecurity, as well as for other existing innovative technologies available in fablabs or citylabs. EDIHs act as single-entry points in accessing tested and validated technologies and promote open innovation.
The network of EDIHs is established through an open and competitive process from among entities designated by Member States. The Commission takes the utmost account of the opinion of each Member State before selecting a European Digital Innovation Hub in the territory of that Member State. The Commission and the Member States should avoid the unnecessary duplication of competences and functions at Union and national level. There should therefore be adequate flexibility when designating the hubs and determining their activities and composition.
The network might be further enlarged through a subsequent open and competitive process.
The network of EDIHs should ensure broad geographical coverage across Europe and should contribute to the participation of the outermost regions in the Digital Single Market.
The European Commission sets up the European Digital Innovation Hubs (EDIHs) in cooperation with Member States.
The DEP is implemented through projects that reinforce and widen the use of essential digital capacities, such as HPC, AI and cybersecurity, and through European Digital Innovation Hubs (EDIHs).

Single Market Programme
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2021/690 establishing a programme for the internal market, competitiveness of enterprises, including small and medium-sized enterprises, the area of plants, animals, food and feed, and European statistics (Single Market Programme) and repealing Regulations (EU) No 99/2013, (EU) No 1287/2013, (EU) No 254/2014 and (EU) No 652/2014
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes the Single Market Programme for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027.
It replaces and repeals Regulations (EU) No 99/2013, (EU) No 1287/2013, (EU) No 254/2014 and (EU) No 652/2014.
KEY POINTS
The Single Market Programme is a financial instrument that supports the European Union (EU) internal market, which is a cornerstone of the EU.
It supports the competitiveness of enterprises, including small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), the area of plants, animals, food and feed, and European statistics.
It aims to improve the functioning of the internal market, while avoiding duplication with related EU programmes and actions.
It includes actions covered by the previous European Statistical Programme established by Regulation (EU) No 99/2013.
It establishes the financial framework for European statistics to provide high-quality, comparable and reliable European statistics, in order to underpin the design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of all EU policies.
It covers the following areas:
competitiveness of enterprises, including SMEs;
consumer protection, customers and end-users in financial services;
policymaking in financial services;
the plant, animal, food and feed area;
European statistics;
the internal market budget lines.
It sets out the types of action that may be supported under the programme:
direct support to public authorities;
grants, financial instruments and budgetary guarantees;
indirect support to public authorities;
indirect support to private entities;
other forms of support;
expenditure outside the EU;
expenditure within the EU.
The programme has a budget of €7.8 billion for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 1 January 2021.

Summary 10:
Firearms — EU rules on their acquisition and possession
Firearms — EU rules on their acquisition and possession
SUMMARY
FROM WHEN
The directive applies from 22 May 2018. It codifies Directive 91/477/EEC which had already been amended several times. The latter directive had applied since 1 January 1992.
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE?
It lays down a comprehensive set of rules on the acquisition and possession of firearms, essential components and ammunition in the European Union (EU). It aims to prevent the illicit trafficking of firearms, their essential components and ammunition and to ensure their effective traceability.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The directive applies to:
firearms (defined in Article 1(1) of the directive), which are portable barrelled weapons that expel a shot, bullet or projectile by the action of a combustible propellant;
essential components of a firearm, such as the barrel, the frame, the receiver, the slide, the cylinder, the bolt or the breech block;
ammunition, including the complete round and its components (cartridge cases, primers, propellant powder, bullets or projectiles);
alarm and signal weapons;
salute and acoustic weapons;
deactivated firearms;
museums and collectors;
dealers and brokers.
Firearms are classified in Part II of Annex I to the directive.
The directive does not apply to:
the acquisition or possession of weapons and ammunition by the armed forces, the police or the public authorities;
transfers regulated by Directive 2009/43/EC.
The directive does not apply to firearms which have been rendered permanently unfit for use by deactivation and which have been rendered permanently inoperable and incapable of removal, replacement or modification in a manner that would permit the firearm to be reactivated in any way.
The directive does not apply to the acquisition or possession of weapons and ammunition by the armed forces, the police or the public authorities.
The directive does not apply to transfers regulated by Directive 2009/43/EEC.
National rules
The acquisition and possession of firearms, essential components and ammunition may be subject to authorisation or prohibition by Member States.
Member States may adopt in their legislation provisions which are more stringent than those laid down in this directive, subject to the rights conferred on residents of the Member States pursuant to Article 17(2).
Firearms must be marked
Member States must ensure that any firearm or any essential component placed on the market has been:
provided with a clear, permanent and unique marking without delay after manufacture and at the latest before its placement on the market, or without delay after importation into the EU;
registered in compliance with this directive without delay after manufacture and at the latest before its placement on the market, or without delay after importation into the EU.
The unique marking must include the name of the manufacturer or brand, the country or place of manufacture, the serial number and the year of manufacture, if not already part of the serial number, and the model where feasible. Where an essential component is too small to be marked in compliance with this directive, it shall be marked at least with a serial number or an alphanumeric or digital code.
Each Member State must ensure that each elementary package of complete ammunition is marked in such a way as to indicate the name of the manufacturer, the batch or lot identification number, the calibre and the type of ammunition.
The marking requirements for firearms or essential components that are of particular historical importance shall be determined in accordance with national law.
The Commission shall adopt implementing acts establishing technical specifications for the marking.
Each Member State must establish a system for the regulation of the activities of dealers and brokers. Such systems must include at least the following measures:
the registration of dealers and brokers operating within the territory of that Member State;
the licensing or authorisation of the activities of dealers and brokers within the territory of that Member State; and
a check of the private and professional integrity and of the relevant abilities of the dealer or broker concerned. In the case of a legal person, the check shall be both on the legal person and on the natural person or persons directing the undertaking.
Member States must ensure the establishment and maintenance of a computerised data-filing system, either centralised or decentralised, which guarantees to authorised authorities access to the data-filing systems in which each firearm subject to this Directive is recorded.
Member States must ensure that the record of firearms and the essential components, including the related personal data, is retained in the data-filing systems by the competent authorities for a period of 30 years after the destruction of the firearms or essential components in question.
The records of firearms and essential components referred to in the first subparagraph of this paragraph and the related personal data shall be capable of being accessed:
by the authorities competent to grant or withdraw authorisations referred to in Article 9 or 10 or by the authorities competent for customs proceedings, for a period of 10 years after the destruction of the firearm or the essential components in question; and
by the authorities competent for the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties, for a period of 30 years after the destruction of the firearm or the essential components in question.
Member States must ensure that personal data are deleted from the data-filing systems upon expiry of the periods specified in the second and third subparagraphs. This shall be without prejudice to cases in which specific personal data have been transferred to an authority competent for the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties and are used in that specific context, or to other authorities competent for a compatible purpose provided for by national law. In such cases, the processing of such data by the competent authorities shall be regulated by the national law of the Member State concerned, in full compliance with Union law, in particular on data protection.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY?
The directive has applied since 22 May 2018.

Summary 11:
Single Window for Maritime Transport
Single Window for Maritime Transport
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2019/1239 on a European Maritime Single Window environment
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to establish a harmonised reporting environment for the maritime transport sector, the so-called European Maritime Single Window environment (EMSWe), in order to facilitate the electronic transmission of information in relation to reporting obligations for ships arriving at, staying in and departing from a port of the European Union (EU).
KEY POINTS
The European Maritime Single Window environment (EMSWe) consists of a network of maritime National Single Windows with harmonised reporting interfaces and includes data exchanges via SafeSeaNet and other relevant systems as well as common services for user registry and access management, addressing, ship identification, location codes and information on dangerous and polluting goods and on health.
Each EU country must establish a maritime National Single Window through which, in accordance with this Regulation and without prejudice to Articles 7 and 11, all information necessary for the fulfilment of reporting obligations must be provided once, by means of and in compliance with the EMSWe data set, using the harmonised reporting interface module and the graphical user interface as set out in Article 6 and, where applicable, other reporting means as set out in Article 7, for the purpose of making this information available to the relevant authorities of the Member States to the extent necessary to allow those authorities to perform their respective functions.
EU countries must establish a maritime National Single Window through which, in accordance with this Regulation and without prejudice to Articles 7 and 11, all information necessary for the fulfilment of reporting obligations must be provided once, by means of and in compliance with the EMSWe data set, using the harmonised reporting interface module and the graphical user interface as set out in Article 6 and, where applicable, other reporting means as set out in Article 7, for the purpose of making this information available to the relevant authorities of the Member States to the extent necessary to allow those authorities to perform their respective functions.
EU countries which do not have maritime ports are exempted from the obligation to develop, establish, operate and make available a maritime National Single Window which is set out in paragraph 1.
The European Commission shall establish and amend the EMSWe data set pursuant to paragraph 3 of this Article.
Where a Member State intends to amend a reporting obligation under in its national legislation and requirements which would involve the provision of information other than the information that is included in the EMSWe data set, that Member State shall immediately notify the Commission. In that notification, the Member State shall precisely identify the information that is not covered by the EMSWe data set and shall indicate the intended period during which the reporting obligation in question is to apply.
The Commission is empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 23 in order to amend the Annex to this Regulation for the purpose of introducing, deleting or adapting references to national legislation or requirements, Union or international legal acts, and in order to establish and amend the EMSWe data set.
The first such delegated act shall be adopted by 15 August 2021.
The Commission shall adopt implementing acts laying down the functional and technical specifications for the harmonised reporting interface module for the maritime National Single Windows.
The first such implementing act shall be adopted by 15 August 2021.
The Commission shall develop by 15 August 2022 and thereafter update the harmonised reporting interface module for the maritime National Single Windows in conformity with the specifications referred to in paragraphs 1 and 5 of this Article.
The Commission shall adopt implementing acts laying down the common functionalities of the graphical user interface and the templates of the harmonised digital spreadsheets referred to in Article 2(9).
The first such implementing act shall be adopted by 15 August 2021.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 15 August 2025.
REFERENCES
Regulation (EU) 2019/1239 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 June 2019 establishing a European Maritime Single Window environment and repealing Directive 2010/65/EU (OJ L 198, 25.7.2019, pp. 64-75).
RELATED DOCUMENTS

Regulation (EU) No 910/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 July 2014 on electronic identification and authentication (OJ L 256, 30.8.2014, pp. 1-9).
Regulation (EU) 2017/352 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 February 2017 establishing a multilateral inspection and training centre for inland navigation and amending Regulation (EC) No 725/2004 (OJ L 75, 17.3.2017, pp. 1-9).

Summary 12:
interoperability of electronic road toll systems and the exchange of information on failure to pay road fees
SUMMARY OF:
Directive (EU) 2019/520 on the interoperability of electronic road toll systems and facilitating cross-border exchange of information on the failure to pay road fees in the Union
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE?
It aims to ensure the interoperability of electronic road toll systems on the entire EU road network, urban and interurban motorways, major and minor roads, and various structures, such as tunnels or bridges, and ferries.
It also aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange of vehicle registration data regarding the vehicles and the owners or holders of vehicles for which there was a failure to pay road fees of any kind in the Union.
It introduces the European Electronic Toll Service (EETS) which aims to ensure the interoperability of electronic road toll systems in the EU.
It does not apply to road toll systems which are not electronic within the meaning of point 10 of Article 2 of the directive.
It does not apply to small, strictly local road toll systems for which the costs of compliance with the requirements of the directive would be disproportionate to the benefits.
It does not apply to parking fees.
It does not apply to failure to pay parking fees.
It does not apply to failure to pay a road fee where the national law requires a notification to the user of the obligation to pay before a failure to pay a road fee can be established.
KEY POINTS
What is an electronic road toll system?
An electronic road toll system is a toll collection system in which the obligation, for the user, to pay the toll is exclusively triggered by and linked to the automatic detection of the presence of the vehicle in a certain location through remote communication with on-board equipment (OBE) in the vehicle or automatic number plate recognition.
What is the European Electronic Toll Service (EETS)?
The EETS is a toll service provided under a contract on one or more EETS domains by an EETS provider to an EETS user.
The EETS provides access to the toll services of several Member States in a single contract and, where necessary, with a single OBE.
What is an EETS domain?
An EETS domain is a road, a road network, a structure, such as a bridge or a tunnel, or a ferry, where tolls are collected using an electronic road toll system.
What is an EETS compliant system?
An EETS compliant system is the set of elements of an electronic road toll system which are specifically needed for the integration of EETS providers in the system and for the operation of EETS.
What is the EETS?
The EETS is a toll service provided under a contract on one or more EETS domains by an EETS provider to an EETS user.
The EETS provides access to the toll services of several Member States in a single contract and, where necessary, with a single OBE.

Summary 13:
EU network of immigration liaison officers
EU network of immigration liaison officers
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2019/1240 — on the creation of a European network of immigration liaison officers
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to enhance the cooperation and coordination among immigration liaison officers* deployed to third countries by Member States, the European Commission and the European agencies by creating a European network of immigration liaison officers.
It also aims to ensure that immigration liaison officers better contribute to the functioning of a European network of immigration liaison officers by establishing a mechanism through which Member States, the Commission and European agencies can more systematically coordinate the tasks and roles of their liaison officers deployed in third countries.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation lays down rules to enhance cooperation and coordination among immigration liaison officers deployed to third countries by Member States, the Commission and European agencies, through the creation of a European network of immigration liaison officers.
It is without prejudice to the responsibility of Member State authorities, the Commission and European agencies for defining the scope and assignment of tasks and reporting lines of their respective immigration liaison officers, and to the tasks of immigration liaison officers within the framework of their responsibilities under Union and national law, policies or procedures, or under special agreements concluded with the host country or international organisations.
Tasks of immigration liaison officers
Immigration liaison officers shall carry out their tasks within the framework of their responsibilities determined by the deploying authorities and in accordance with the provisions, including those on the protection of personal data, laid down in Union and national laws and in any agreements or arrangements concluded with third countries or international organisations.
Immigration liaison officers shall carry out their tasks in accordance with fundamental rights as general principles of Union law as well as international law, including human rights obligations. They shall have particular consideration for vulnerable persons and take into account the gender dimension of migration flows.
Each deploying authority shall ensure that immigration liaison officers establish and maintain direct contacts with the competent authorities of third countries, including, when appropriate, with local authorities, and any relevant organisations operating within the third country, including international organisations, notably with a view to implementing this regulation.
Immigration liaison officers shall collect information, for use either at operational level, strategic level, or both. Information collected under this paragraph shall be collected in accordance with Article 1(2) and shall not contain personal data, without prejudice to Article 10(2). Such information shall cover the following issues in particular:
the European integrated border management at the external borders, with a view to managing migration effectively;
migratory flows originating from or transiting through the third country, including where possible and relevant, the composition of migratory flows and migrants’ intended destination;
routes used by migratory flows originating from or transiting through the third country in order to reach the territories of the Member States;
the existence, activities and modi operandi of criminal organisations involved in smuggling of migrants and trafficking in human beings along the migratory routes;
incidents and events that have the potential to be or to cause new developments with respect to migratory flows;
methods used for counterfeiting or falsifying identity documents and travel documents;
ways and means to assist the authorities in third countries in preventing illegal immigration flows originating from or transiting through their territories;
pre-departure measures available to immigrants in the country of origin or in host third countries that support successful integration upon legal arrival in Member States;
facilitating return, readmission and reintegration;
effective access to protection that the third country has put in place, including in favour of vulnerable persons;
existing and possible future legal immigration strategies and channels between the Union and third countries, taking into account skills and labour market needs in Member States, as well as resettlement and other protection tools;
capacity, capability, political strategies, legislation and legal practices of third countries and stakeholders, including, where possible and relevant, regarding reception and detention centres and the conditions therein, as relevant to the issues referred to in points (a) to (k).
Immigration liaison officers may render assistance, taking into account their expertise and training, in:
establishing the identity and nationality of third-country nationals and facilitating their return in accordance with Directive 2008/115/EC, as well as assisting their reintegration, where relevant and possible;
confirming the identity of persons in need of international protection for the purposes of facilitating their resettlement in the Union, including by providing them, where possible, with adequate pre-departure information and support;
confirming identity and facilitating implementation of Union and national measures in respect of the admission of legal immigrants;
sharing information obtained in the course of their duties within networks of immigration liaison officers and with competent authorities of the Member States, including law enforcement authorities, in order to prevent and detect illegal immigration as well as combat smuggling of migrants and trafficking in human beings.
Notification of the deployment of immigration liaison officers
Member States, the Commission and the European agencies shall inform the Steering Board established in Article 7 of their plans for and actual deployment of immigration liaison officers, including a description of their duties and the duration of their deployment.
The activity reports referred to in point (c) of Article 8(2) shall include an overview of the deployments of immigration liaison officers.
Creation of local or regional networks of immigration liaison officers
Immigration liaison officers deployed to the same countries or regions shall constitute local or regional cooperation networks and cooperate, where and when appropriate, with liaison officers deployed by countries other than Member States. Within the framework of such networks, immigration liaison officers shall in accordance with Article 1(2), in particular:
meet regularly and whenever necessary;
exchange information and practical experience, in particular at meetings and via the secure web-based information exchange platform provided for in Article 9;
exchange information, where appropriate, on experience regarding access to international protection;
coordinate positions to be adopted in contacts with commercial carriers, where appropriate;
attend joint specialised training courses, when appropriate, including on fundamental rights, trafficking in human beings, smuggling of migrants, document fraud or access to international protection in third countries;
organise information sessions and training courses for members of the diplomatic and consular staff of the missions of the Member States in the third country, when appropriate;
adopt common approaches on methods for the collection and reporting of strategically relevant information, including risk analyses;
set up regular contacts with similar networks in the third country and in neighbouring third countries, as appropriate.
Immigration liaison officers deployed by the Commission shall facilitate and support the networks provided for in paragraph 1. In locations where the Commission does not deploy immigration liaison officers, immigration liaison officers deployed by European agencies shall facilitate and support the networks provided for in paragraph 1. In locations where neither the Commission nor European agencies deploy immigration liaison officers, the network shall be facilitated by an immigration liaison officer, as agreed by members of the network.
The Steering Board shall be notified without undue delay of the appointment of the designated network facilitator or where no facilitator is designated.
Joint deployment of immigration liaison officers
Member States may bilaterally or multilaterally agree that immigration liaison officers who are deployed to a third country or international organisation by a Member State shall also look after the interests of one or more other Member States.
Where two or more Member States jointly deploy an immigration liaison officer, those Member States may receive Union financial support pursuant to Regulation (EU) No 515/2014.
Steering Board
A Steering Board for a European network of immigration liaison officers is



Summary 14:
Strengthening the security of identity cards of EU citizens and of residence documents issued to EU citizens and their family members exercising their right of free movement
Strengthening the security of identity cards of EU citizens and of residence documents issued to EU citizens and their family members exercising their right of free movement
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2019/1157 — strengthening the security of identity cards of Union citizens and of residence documents issued to Union citizens and their family members exercising their right of free movement
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to strengthen the security of identity cards and residence documents issued to EU citizens and their family members exercising their right of free movement.
The regulation does not provide a legal basis for setting up or maintaining databases at national level for the storage of biometric data in EU countries, which is a matter of national law that needs to comply with EU law regarding data protection.
It also does not provide a legal basis for setting up or maintaining a centralised database at EU level.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to:
identity cards issued by EU countries to their own nationals;
registration certificates issued in accordance with Article 8 of Directive 2004/38/EC (see summary) to EU citizens residing for more than 3 months in a host EU country and documents certifying permanent residence issued in accordance with Article 19 of that directive;
residence cards issued in accordance with Article 10 of Directive 2004/38/EC to family members of EU citizens who are not nationals of an EU country and permanent residence cards issued in accordance with Article 20 of Directive 2004/38/EC to family members of EU citizens who are not nationals of an EU country.
Security standards
Identity cards issued by EU countries shall be produced in ID-1 format and shall contain a machine-readable zone (MRZ). Such identity cards shall be based on the specifications and minimum security standards set out in ICAO Document 9303 and shall comply with the requirements set out in points (c), (d), (f) and (g) of the Annex to Regulation (EC) No 1030/2002.
The data elements included on identity cards shall comply with the specifications set out in part 5 of ICAO document 9303.
The document shall bear the title ‘Identity card’ or another well-established national designation in the official language or languages of the issuing EU country, and the words ‘Identity card’ in at least one other official language of the institutions of the Union.
The identity card shall contain, on the front side, the 2-letter country code of the EU country issuing the card, printed in negative in a blue rectangle and encircled by 12 yellow stars.
Identity cards shall include a highly secure storage medium which shall contain a facial image of the holder of the card and two fingerprints in interoperable digital formats. For the capture of biometric identifiers, EU countries shall apply the technical specifications as established by Commission Implementing Decision C(2018) 7767.
The storage medium shall have sufficient capacity and capability to guarantee the integrity, the authenticity and the confidentiality of the data. The data stored shall be accessible in contactless form and secured as provided for in Implementing Decision C(2018) 7767. EU countries shall exchange the information necessary to authenticate the storage medium and to access and verify the biometric data referred to in the above paragraph.
Children under the age of 12 years may be exempt from the requirement to give fingerprints.
Children under the age of 6 years shall be exempt from the requirement to give fingerprints.
Persons in respect of whom fingerprinting is physically impossible shall be exempt from the requirement to give fingerprints.
Where EU countries incorporate a dual interface or a separate storage medium in the identity card, the additional storage medium shall comply with the relevant ISO standards and shall not interfere with the storage medium referred to in the above paragraph.
Where EU countries store data for electronic services such as e-government and e-business in the identity cards, such national data shall be physically or logically separated from the biometric data referred to in the above paragraph.
Where EU countries add additional security features to identity cards, the cross-border compatibility of such identity cards and the efficiency of the minimum security standards shall not be diminished as a result.
Identity cards shall have a minimum period of validity of 5 years and a maximum period of validity of 10 years.
Identity cards which do not meet the requirements set out in the regulation shall cease to be valid at their expiry or by 3 August 2031, whichever is earlier.
By way of derogation from the above, identity cards which do not meet the minimum security standards set out in part 2 of ICAO document 9303 or which do not include a functional MRZ shall cease to be valid at their expiry or by 3 August 2026, whichever is earlier.
Residence documents
Residence documents issued to EU citizens shall indicate at a minimum the following:
the title of the document in the official language or languages of the EU country concerned and in at least one other official language of the institutions of the Union;
a clear reference that the document is issued to a Union citizen in accordance with Directive 2004/38/EC;
the document number;
the name (surname and forename(s)) of the holder;
the date of birth of the holder;
the information to be included on registration certificates and documents certifying permanent residence, issued in accordance with Articles 8 and 19 of Directive 2004/38/EC, respectively;
the issuing authority;
on the front-side, the 2-letter country code of the EU country issuing the document, printed in negative in a blue rectangle and encircled by 12 yellow stars.
If an EU country decides to take fingerprints, Article 3(7) shall apply accordingly.
Persons in respect of whom fingerprinting is physically impossible shall be exempt from the requirement to give fingerprints.
Residence cards
When issuing residence cards to family members of EU citizens who are not nationals of an EU country, EU countries shall use the same format as established by Regulation (EC) No 1030/2002 as amended by Regulation (EU) 2017/1954, and as implemented by Implementing Decision C(2018) 7767.
By way of derogation from the above, a card shall bear the title ‘Residence card’ or ‘Permanent residence card’. EU countries shall indicate that these documents are issued to a family member of a Union citizen in accordance with Directive 2004/38/EC. For this purpose, EU countries shall use the standardised code ‘Family Member EU Art 10 DIR 2004/38/EC’ or ‘Family Member EU Art 20 DIR 2004/38/EC’, in data field [10], as referred to in the Annex to Regulation (EC) No 1030/2002 as amended by Regulation (EU) 2017/1954.
EU countries may enter data for national use in accordance with national law. When entering and storing such data, EU countries shall respect the requirements set out in the second paragraph of Article 4 of Regulation (EC) No 1030/2002 as amended by Regulation (EU) 2017/1954.
Residence cards of family members of EU citizens who are not

EU information systems and interoperability
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes a framework for interoperability between EU information systems in the field of borders and visa. It also amends Regulations (EC) No 767/2008, (EU) 2016/399, (EU) 2017/2226, (EU) 2018/1240, (EU) 2018/1726 and (EU) 2018/1861 of the European Parliament and of the Council and Council Decisions 2004/512/EC and 2008/633/JHA.
KEY POINTS
The European Commission has proposed a new approach to the management of data for borders, security and migration. All EU information systems for security, border and migration management are to be interoperable, in a manner fully respecting fundamental rights.

Summary 16:
EU renewable energy directive
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS DIRECTIVE DO?
It sets a binding renewable energy target for 2030 of at least 32% of the final energy consumption in the EU.
It requires EU countries to set out how they intend to meet their share of the 2030 target in their integrated national energy and climate plans.
It also sets out a number of measures for the EU countries to implement to achieve the 2030 target, including:
an obligation to produce 10% of their total heating and cooling needs from renewable sources by 2020;
a requirement to use renewable electricity in transport, with a 14% share of renewable energy in the transport sector by 2030.
KEY POINTS
Binding renewable energy target
The directive sets a binding renewable energy target for 2030 of at least 32% of the final energy consumption in the EU.
The 2030 target is a step up from the 20% target for 2020. It means that the EU will have to produce 33% of its energy from renewable sources by 2030, compared to 16% in 2015.
EU countries’ contributions to the 2030 target
EU countries must set out how they intend to meet their share of the 2030 target in their integrated national energy and climate plans.
These plans must include a detailed description of how the EU country will meet its 2030 target. The plans must include a detailed description of how the EU country will meet its 2030 target, including:
a breakdown of the renewable energy production of the EU country;
an estimate of the renewable energy production of neighbouring EU countries and the extent to which it could be consumed in the EU country;
an estimate of the renewable energy that could be imported from third countries;
the renewable energy potential of the EU country, including the potential for renewable energy in waste and residues;
an estimate of the renewable energy consumption of the EU country;
the national renewable energy target;
the contribution of renewable energy to the EU target;
the contribution of renewable energy to the EU country’s greenhouse gas emission reduction target;
the contribution of renewable energy to the EU country’s energy efficiency target;
the share of renewable heating and cooling;

Summary 17:
European Electronic Communications Code
The European Electronic Communications Code aims to boost investment in very high capacity networks and to provide end-users with a better internet experience. It also aims to ensure the efficient use of radio spectrum and to make the internal market for electronic communications more predictable and more consistent.
WHAT DOES THIS DIRECTIVE DO?
It establishes a European Electronic Communications Code. This code covers both the provision of electronic communications networks and services.
The directive covers all types of electronic communications networks and services, including those using radio spectrum.
The directive replaces 4 directives on the subject: the authorisation directive, the access directive, the universal service directive and the regulatory framework directive.
KEY POINTS
The directive establishes a new regulatory framework for electronic communications networks and services in the EU. It aims to ensure that:
very high capacity networks are progressively rolled out across the EU;
end-users are provided with a better internet experience;
the radio spectrum is efficiently used;
the internal market for electronic communications is more predictable and consistent.
The directive defines 3 types of services which may partly overlap:
internet access services: these are services that enable subscribers or end-users to connect to a public communications network and access and exchange data using internet protocol technology.
interpersonal communications services: these are services that enable interpersonal and interactive exchange of information, covering services like traditional voice calls between two individuals but also all types of emails, messaging services, or group chats.
services consisting wholly or mainly in the conveyance of signals: these are services that enable communications between a finite, that is to say not potentially unlimited, number of natural persons, which is determined by the sender of the communication.
The directive also defines 3 types of networks:
fixed networks: these are networks which enable communications between end-users via a wired geography.
wireless networks: these are networks which enable communications between end-users via a wireless geography.
very high capacity networks: these are networks that are capable of providing at least 30 Mbps to each end-user, and which are promptly upgradeable to gigabit speeds.
The directive establishes a number of objectives for the national regulatory authorities. These are to:
ensure the availability of very high capacity networks across the EU;
ensure the availability of uninterrupted 5G coverage for urban areas and major terrestrial transport paths;
ensure that all households in each Member State have access to electronic communications networks which are capable of providing at least 100 Mbps and which are promptly upgradeable to gigabit speeds;
ensure that 5G coverage is available across the Union for the most important socio-economic drivers such as schools, transport hubs and major providers of public services, and highly digitised businesses.
The directive also establishes a number of principles that national regulatory authorities must respect. These are to:
ensure that the regulatory framework is technologically neutral;
ensure that the regulatory framework is market driven;
ensure that the regulatory framework is cost oriented;
ensure that the regulatory framework is risk based;
ensure that the regulatory framework is proportionate.
The directive establishes a number of principles that national regulatory authorities may respect. These are to:
ensure that the regulatory framework is market based;
ensure that the regulatory framework is market driven;
ensure that the regulatory framework is market led;
ensure that the regulatory framework is competition led;
ensure that the regulatory framework is risk based;
ensure that the regulatory framework is risk led;
ensure that the regulatory framework is market led;
ensure that the regulatory framework is risk based;
ensure that the regulatory framework is risk led;
ensure that the regulatory framework is cost driven;
ensure that the regulatory framework is cost based;
ensure that the regulatory framework is cost led;
ensure that the regulatory framework is proportionate;
ensure that the regulatory framework is transparent.
The directive establishes a number of principles that national regulatory authorities should respect. These are to:
ensure that the regulatory framework is proportionate;
ensure that the regulatory framework is transparent;

Summary 18:
CO2 emissions from heavy-duty vehicles
SUMMARY
CO2 emissions from heavy-duty vehicles
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to reduce CO2 emissions from new heavy-duty vehicles (lorries, buses and coaches) and their fuel consumption. It establishes a system to monitor and report the emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles registered in the EU.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to new heavy-duty vehicles registered in the EU, with the exception of vehicles falling within the scope of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 (CO2 emissions from passenger cars and light commercial vehicles) and Regulation (EC) No 595/2009 (emissions from heavy-duty vehicles).
For the purposes of this regulation, heavy-duty vehicles are those of categories M1, M2, N1 and N2 with a reference mass that exceeds 2 610 kg and which do not fall within the scope of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007, and all vehicles of categories M3 and N3.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 29 July 2018.
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It requires Member States and manufacturers to monitor and report data on new heavy-duty vehicles.
It sets out the data to be monitored and reported by Member States and manufacturers, the monitoring and reporting procedure and the administrative fines that may be imposed on manufacturers.
It requires the Commission to keep a central register for the data on heavy-duty vehicles.
It requires the Commission to monitor the results of on-road verification tests.
It sets out the rules for the amendment of the Annexes to the regulation.
It establishes a committee procedure for the Commission to consult.
The Commission may adopt delegated and implementing acts to complete the starting years for the monitoring and reporting of data for the heavy-duty vehicle categories covered, to amend the data requirements and the monitoring and reporting procedure, to specify the data to be reported by the Member States for the monitoring of the results of on-road verification tests, to amend the air drag value ranges, and to define the criteria, the calculation and the method of collection of administrative fines imposed on manufacturers.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 29 July 2018.
