Summary 62:
European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Displaced Workers (EGF) and repealing Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013
European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Displaced Workers (EGF) and repealing Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Displaced Workers (EGF) for the period of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027.
It lays down the objectives of the EGF, the forms of Union funding and the rules for providing such funding, including applications by the Member States for financial contributions from the EGF for measures targeting the beneficiaries referred to in Article 6.
KEY POINTS
The EGF shall support socioeconomic transformations that are the result of globalisation and of technological and environmental changes by helping displaced workers and self-employed persons whose activity has ceased to adapt to structural change. The EGF shall constitute an emergency fund that operates reactively. As such, the EGF shall contribute to the implementation of the principles set out in the European Pillar of Social Rights and shall enhance social and economic cohesion among regions and Member States.
The objectives of the EGF are to demonstrate solidarity and promote decent and sustainable employment in the Union by offering assistance in the case of major restructuring events, in particular those caused by challenges related to globalisation, such as changes in world trade patterns, trade disputes, significant changes in the trade relations of the Union or the composition of the internal market and financial or economic crises, as well as the transition to a low-carbon economy, or as a consequence of digitisation or automation. The EGF shall support beneficiaries in returning to decent and sustainable employment as soon as possible. Particular emphasis shall be placed on measures that help the most disadvantaged groups.
The EGF shall support workers who lose their jobs in large-scale restructuring events and to help them to find other jobs as quickly as possible. The Union shall continue to provide specific, one-off support to facilitate the reintegration into decent and sustainable employment of displaced workers in areas, sectors, territories or labour markets suffering a shock of serious economic disruption.
The EGF shall be mobilised in cases where a major restructuring event has a significant impact on the local or regional economy. Such an impact shall be determined by reference to a minimum number of job displacements within a specific reference period. Considering that waves of dismissals in different sectors within the same region have an equally significant impact on the local labour market, regional applications shall also be possible. In small labour markets, such as in small Member States or remote regions, including the outermost regions as referred in Article 349 TFEU, or in exceptional circumstances, it shall be possible for applications to be submitted in cases with a lower number of job displacements. In general, Member States shall not submit their applications for EGF assistance later than 12 weeks after the end of the reference period. However, in order to prevent a funding gap due to the fact that this Regulation will enter into force after 1 January 2021 and in order to provide legal certainty, that time limit shall be suspended between 1 January 2021 and the entry into force of this Regulation.
The EGF shall primarily direct financial contributions towards active labour market policy measures and personalised services that aim to reintegrate beneficiaries rapidly into decent and sustainable employment within or outside their initial sector of activity, while preparing them for a greener and more digital European economy. The support shall also seek to promote self-employment and enterprise creation, including through the establishment of cooperatives. Measures shall reflect the prospective needs of the local or regional labour market. However, where relevant, the mobility of displaced workers shall also be supported in order to help them find new employment elsewhere. There shall be a particular focus on the dissemination of skills required in the digital age and on overcoming gender stereotypes in employment, where appropriate. The inclusion of pecuniary allowances in coordinated packages of personalised services shall be restricted. The measures supported by the EGF shall not replace passive social protection measures. Employers could be encouraged to participate in the national co-funding for the EGF-supported measures in addition to the measures which they are required to provide by virtue of national law or collective agreements.
The EGF shall be mobilised in cases where a major restructuring event has a significant impact on the local or regional economy. Such an impact shall be determined by reference to a minimum number of job displacements within a specific reference period. Considering that waves of dismissals in different sectors within the same region have an equally significant impact on the local labour market, regional applications shall also be possible. In small labour markets, such as in small Member States or remote regions, including the outermost regions as referred in Article 349 TFEU, or in exceptional circumstances, it shall be possible for applications to be submitted in cases with a lower number of job displacements. In general, Member States shall not submit their applications for EGF assistance later than 12 weeks after the end of the reference period. However, in order to prevent a funding gap due to the fact that this Regulation will enter into force after 1 January 2021 and in order to provide legal certainty, that time limit shall be suspended between 1 January 2021 and the entry into force of this Regulation.

Summary 64:
budget discipline, cooperation, sound financial management and new own resources
SUMMARY OF:
Interinstitutional Agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management, as well as on new own resources, including a roadmap towards the introduction of new own resources
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE AGREEMENT?
It aims to implement budgetary discipline, improve the functioning of the annual budgetary procedure and cooperation between the institutions on budgetary matters, as well as to ensure sound financial management, and to implement a cooperation and establish a roadmap towards the introduction, over the period of the multiannual financial framework 2021-2027 (MFF 2021-2027), of new own resources that are sufficient to cover the repayment of the European Union Recovery Instrument established under Council Regulation (EU) 2020/2094.
It does not alter the respective budgetary and legislative powers of the institutions as laid down in the Treaties, in Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2020/2093 (the MFF Regulation), in Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2018/1046 (the Financial Regulation) and in Council Decision (EU, Euratom) 2020/2053 (the Own Resources Decision), and is without prejudice to the powers of national parliaments in respect of own resources.
The agreement is in four parts:
part I contains provisions related to the multiannual financial framework (MFF) and to the thematic and non-thematic special instruments;
part II relates to interinstitutional cooperation in budgetary matters;
part III contains provisions related to the sound financial management of Union funds;
part IV contains provisions related to the quality and comparability of data on beneficiaries in the context of the protection of the Union budget.
KEY TERMS
• Multiannual financial framework: the legal framework for the European Union (EU) budget for the 7 years starting from 1 January 2021.
• Thematic and non-thematic special instruments: the thematic and non-thematic instruments of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) and the European territorial cooperation goal (previously known as the cohesion policy goal).
WHEN DOES THE AGREEMENT APPLY?
It applies from 16 December 2020 and replaces the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management.
FROM WHEN DOES THIS AGREEMENT APPLY?
The agreement applies from 16 December 2020.
BACKGROUND
The MFF 2021-2027 provides the EU with the necessary financial means to implement its policies and programmes, including those that contribute to the recovery from the COVID-19 crisis. It establishes a total budget of €1 095 000 million for the 7 years starting from 1 January 2021.
The European Commission’s proposal for a new MFF 2021-2027 was adopted on 25 May 2021. It sets out the EU’s financial priorities for the coming 7 years. It provides for a total amount of €1 095 000 million for the period 2021-2027, which is a 50% increase compared to the previous MFF 2014-2020.
KEY FACTS

part I contains provisions related to the multiannual financial framework (MFF) and to the thematic and non-thematic special instruments;
part II relates to interinstitutional cooperation in budgetary matters;

part IV contains provisions related to the quality and comparability of data on beneficiaries in the context of the protection of the Union budget.
The agreement does not alter the respective budgetary and legislative powers of the institutions as laid down in the Treaties, in Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2020/2093 (the MFF Regulation), in Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2018/1046 (the Financial Regulation) and in Council Decision (EU, Euratom) 2020/2053 (the Own Resources Decision), and is without prejudice to the powers of national parliaments in respect of own resources.
The agreement is binding on the institutions for as long as it is in force.

Part II: interinstitutional cooperation procedure
Part III: sound financial management of Union funds

FROM WHEN DOES THIS AGREEMENT APPLY?
The agreement applies from 16 December 2020.

Summary 65:
European Recovery Instrument
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the European Union Recovery Instrument (the Instrument) to support the recovery in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis.
KEY POINTS
The Instrument is designed to support:
measures to restore labour markets and social protection as well as health care systems;
measures to reinvigorate potential for sustainable growth and employment;
measures for businesses affected by the impact of the COVID-19 crisis;
measures for research and innovation in response to the COVID-19 crisis;
measures for increasing the level of the Union’s crisis preparedness and enabling a quick and effective Union response in the event of major emergencies;
measures to ensure that a just transition to a climate-neutral economy will not be undermined by the COVID-19 crisis;
measures to address the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on agriculture and rural development.
The Instrument is to be implemented through specific Union programmes, such as structural and cohesion programmes of the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020 as reinforced until 2022, a programme financing recovery and economic and social resilience via support to reforms and investments, programmes related to civil protection, programmes related to research and innovation, programmes supporting territories in their transition towards a climate-neutral economy, programmes supporting development in rural areas.
The Instrument is to be financed up to an amount of EUR 750 000 million in 2018 prices, of which:
EUR 384 400 million in 2018 prices is to be allocated as non-repayable support and repayable support through financial instruments;
EUR 360 000 million in 2018 prices is to be allocated as loans to Member States;
EUR 5 600 million in 2018 prices is to be allocated as provisioning for budgetary guarantees and related expenditure for programmes aiming at supporting investment operations in the field of Union internal policies.
For the purpose of Article 21(5) of the Financial Regulation, EUR 384 400 million in 2018 prices, of the amount referred to in Article 2(1) of this Regulation, shall constitute external assigned revenue to the Union programmes referred to in point (a) of Article 2(2) of this Regulation and EUR 5 600 million in 2018 prices of that amount shall constitute external assigned revenue to the Union programmes referred to in point (c) of Article 2(2) of this Regulation.
The Commission shall submit to the Council a report on the progress achieved in the implementation of the Instrument and the use of the funds allocated in accordance with Article 2(2) by 31 October 2022.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from the day following its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union.
REFERENCES
Act
Entry into force
Deadline for implementation in the Member States
Regulation (EU) 2020/2094

Summary 67:
EU census — data on population and housing
EU census — data on population and housing
Population and housing censuses are a key source of information for the European Union (EU) and its Member States. The European Parliament and the Council have adopted a Regulation on population and housing censuses. The Regulation establishes common rules for the decennial provision of comprehensive data on population and housing.
ACT
Regulation (EC) No 763/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 July 2008 on population and housing censuses.
KEY TERMS
Population: the national, regional and local population at its usual residence at the reference date.
Housing: living quarters and buildings as well as housing arrangements and the relationship between the population and living quarters at the national, regional and local levels at the reference date.
Reference date: the date to which the data of the respective Member State refer, in accordance with Article 5(1).
WHAT DIFFERENCE DOES THIS REGULATION MAKE?
The Regulation establishes common rules for the decennial provision of comprehensive data on population and housing.
It covers the following:
data on the population covering determined demographic, social and economic characteristics of persons, families and households, as well as on housing at a national, regional and local level;
the reference date for the transmission of data;
the transmission of data and metadata to the European Commission (Eurostat);
the quality assessment of the data;
the conditions for the establishment of subsequent reference years and the adoption of the programme of the statistical data and the metadata.
The Regulation applies to the following:
population;
housing;
buildings;
usual residence;
reference date;
national;
regional;
local;
essential features of population and housing censuses.
The Regulation does not apply to:
the transmission of data and metadata on the following:
—
agricultural land and agricultural buildings;
—
industrial buildings;
—
non-residential buildings.
WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
The Regulation applies from 20 August 2008.
BACKGROUND
The European Union (EU) needs to be in possession of sufficiently reliable, detailed and comparable data on the population and housing, in order to enable it to fulfil the tasks assigned to it, in particular by Articles 2 and 3 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
The Regulation covers data on the population and housing, which are key sources of information for the EU and its Member States. The decennial provision of comprehensive data on population and housing is necessary for the study and definition of regional, social and environmental policies affecting particular sectors of the Community.
KEY FACTS
Census
A census is a survey of the population of a country or area carried out at regular intervals, usually every 10 years.
Population and housing censuses
Population and housing censuses are a key source of information for the EU and its Member States. The decennial provision of comprehensive data on population and housing is necessary for the study and definition of regional, social and environmental policies affecting particular sectors of the Community.

non-residential buildings.

Summary 68:
Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament — 9th parliamentary term
Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament — 9th parliamentary term
SUMMARY OF:
Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament — 9th parliamentary term
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE RULES?
The Rules of Procedure set out the procedures for the European Parliament, its committees and delegations, its relations with other institutions and bodies, and its relations with national parliaments.
KEY POINTS
The European Parliament is the assembly elected pursuant to the Treaties, the Act of 20 September 1976 concerning the election of the members of the European Parliament by direct universal suffrage and national legislation deriving from the Treaties.
The European Parliament may adopt, by a majority of the votes cast, any opinion or resolution intended for it by the Treaties or by the Act of 20 September 1976.
The European Parliament may adopt, by a majority of the votes cast, any opinion or resolution intended for it by the Treaties or by the Act of 20 September 1976.
Members of the European Parliament
Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) exercise their mandate freely and independently, are not bound by any instructions and do not receive a binding mandate.
MEPs are entitled to participate actively in the work of the European Parliament’s committees and delegations.
Rules of Procedure
The Rules of Procedure are divided into 14 titles:
Members, Parliament bodies and political groups;
Legislative, budgetary, discharge and other procedures;
International agreements;
Transparency of business;
Relations with other institutions and bodies;
Sessions;
Committees and delegations;
Petitions;
Ombudsman;
Parliament’s Secretariat;
Powers and responsibilities relating to European political parties and European political foundations;
Application and amendment of the Rules of Procedure;
Miscellaneous provisions.
FROM WHEN DO THE RULES APPLY?
The Rules apply from 1 July 2019.

Decision of the European Data Protection Supervisor adopting the Rules of Procedure of the EDPS
SUMMARY OF:
Decision of the European Data Protection Supervisor adopting the Rules of Procedure of the EDPS
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION?
It aims to ensure that the European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS) and its Secretariat, which consists of the Secretariat of the European Data Protection Board (EDPB), act in a consistent manner, in accordance with the applicable legal framework and this Decision, and that they implement the strategic priorities that the EDPS may set out.
KEY POINTS
The EDPS
The EDPS is an independent body responsible for ensuring that the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, and in particular their right to data protection, are respected by the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies.
The EDPS is responsible for the following tasks:
ensuring the application of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and the Regulation (EU) 2018/1725, which provides for the tasks and powers of the EDPS;
monitoring the development of information and communication technologies insofar as they have an impact on the protection of personal data;
issuing opinions and formal comments in response to requests from the European Commission;
cooperating with national supervisory authorities;
intervening in actions brought before the Court of Justice of the European Union;
cooperating with the EDPB;
issuing annual reports and strategic priorities;
ensuring the application of the GDPR and Regulation (EU) 2018/1725;
ensuring the application of Regulation (EU) 2016/794, which provides for the tasks and powers of the EDPS;
ensuring the application of Regulation (EU) 2018/1727, which provides for the tasks and powers of the EDPS;
ensuring the application of Regulation (EU) 2017/1939, which provides for the tasks and powers of the EDPS.
The EDPS may also contribute to the Union’s Framework Programmes and serve on the advisory committees of research projects.
The EDPS may decide to contribute to the Union’s Framework Programmes and to serve on the advisory committees of research projects.

Guiding principles
The EDPS shall act in the public’s interest as an expert as well as an independent, reliable, proactive and authoritative body in the field of privacy and personal data protection.
The EDPS shall act in accordance with the EDPS Ethics Framework.
The EDPS shall act in accordance with the following principles:
good governance, integrity and good administrative behaviour;
accountability and transparency;
efficiency and effectiveness;

Summary 70:
EU budget: new own resources, new borrowing powers and new rules for the future
EU budget: new own resources, new borrowing powers and new rules for the future
The EU’s financial resources will be increased in order to deal with the consequences of the COVID-19 crisis. The new own resources will be introduced gradually over the next few years. In addition, the EU will be able to borrow up to €750 billion in order to address the consequences of the COVID-19 crisis. In the future, the EU will work towards the introduction of other own resources.
WHAT IS THE AIMS OF THE DECISION?
It sets out new own resources to help the EU deal with the consequences of the COVID-19 crisis. It also introduces new borrowing powers to address the consequences of the COVID-19 crisis. In the future, the EU will work towards the introduction of other own resources.
KEY POINTS
The new own resources
The decision sets out 4 new own resources:
a uniform call rate of 0.30 % on VAT collected in the EU;
a uniform call rate of €0.80 per kilogram on plastic packaging waste;
a uniform call rate on GNI (gross national income);
a lump sum reduction of the GNI-based contributions for certain countries.
The new own resources will be introduced gradually over the next few years.
The decision sets out the ceilings for the EU’s annual budget. The decision also sets out the conditions for the introduction of new own resources.
The new borrowing powers
The decision sets out the conditions for the EU to borrow up to €750 billion to address the consequences of the COVID-19 crisis. The repayment of the principal of the funds borrowed to be used for expenditure and the related interest due will be borne by the EU budget.
The EU will manage the borrowing so that no new net borrowing takes place after 2026.
The repayment of the principal of the funds borrowed to be used for expenditure and the related interest due will be scheduled, in accordance with the principle of sound financial management, so as to ensure the steady and predictable reduction of liabilities. Repayments of the principal of the funds shall start before the end of the MFF 2021-2027 period, with a minimum amount, insofar as amounts not used for interest payments due under the borrowing allow it, with due regard to the procedure set out in Article 314 TFEU. All liabilities incurred by the exceptional and temporary empowerment of the Commission to borrow funds referred to in the decision will be fully repaid at the latest by 31 December 2058.
The decision sets out the conditions for the use of the funds borrowed on capital markets. The EU will not use the funds borrowed on capital markets for the financing of operational expenditure.
The decision sets out the conditions for the administration of the borrowing operations. The Commission will regularly and comprehensively inform the European Parliament and the Council about all aspects of its debt management strategy. The Commission will establish an issuance calendar containing the expected issuance dates and volumes for the forthcoming year as well as a plan setting out the expected principal and interest payments, and communicate it to the European Parliament and the Council. The Commission will update that calendar regularly.
The future
The decision sets out the conditions for the introduction of other own resources.
The European Council of 17-21 July 2020 invited the Commission to put forward in the first semester of 2021 proposals on a carbon border adjustment mechanism and on a digital levy with a view to their introduction at the latest by 1 January 2023. The European Council invited the Commission to put forward a revised proposal on the EU Emissions Trading System, possibly extending it to the aviation and maritime sectors.
The decision sets out the conditions for the introduction of new own resources by 1 January 2023 at the latest.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY?
The decision applies from 1 January 2021.

Summary 72:
customs control equipment to protect the EU’s borders
Customs control equipment to protect the EU’s borders
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2021/1077 establishing, as part of the Integrated Border Management Fund, the instrument for financial support for customs control equipment
WHAT IS THE AIMS OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to establish an instrument for financial support for customs control equipment, as part of the Integrated Border Management Fund, for the period 2021-2027.
The instrument’s aim is to support the customs union and customs authorities in their mission to protect the financial and economic interests of the EU and its Member States, to ensure security and safety within the EU and to protect the EU from illegal trade while facilitating legitimate business activity.
The regulation also lays down the objectives of the instrument, the budget for the period 2021-2027, the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding.
KEY POINTS
The instrument may provide funding in any of the forms laid down in the Financial Regulation, and in particular by means of grants.
The financial envelope for the instrument for the period 2021-2027 is €1.006 billion in current prices. This may also cover expenses for preparation, monitoring, control, audit, evaluation and other activities for managing the instrument and evaluating the achievement of its objectives.
The instrument may provide funding in any of the forms laid down in the Financial Regulation and in particular by means of grants.
Eligible actions
In order for actions to be eligible for funding under the instrument, those actions must comply with the following requirements:
implement the objectives set out in Article 3;
support the purchase, maintenance or upgrading of customs control equipment including innovative detection technology equipment, that has one or more of the following customs control purposes:
non-intrusive inspection;
indication of hidden objects on humans;
radiation detection and nuclide identification;
analysis of samples in laboratories;
sampling and field analysis of samples;
handheld search.
The Commission may adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 14 to amend this Regulation by updating, where necessary, the indicative list of customs control equipment set out in Annex I.
Eligible entities
The eligible entities shall be the customs authorities on condition that they provide the information necessary for the assessment of needs.
The instrument may finance up to 80 % of the total eligible costs of an action.
The following costs shall not be eligible for funding under the instrument:
costs related to the purchase of land;
costs relating to training or the upgrading of skills, other than the introductory training included in the purchase or upgrade contract;
costs relating to infrastructure, such as buildings or outdoor facilities, as well as to furniture;
costs associated with electronic systems, with the exception of software and software updates directly necessary to use the customs control equipment and with the exception of the electronic software and programming necessary to interlink existing software with the customs control equipment;
costs of networks, such as secured or unsecured communication channels, or subscriptions, with the exception of networks or subscriptions exclusively necessary to use the customs control equipment;
costs of transport means, such as vehicles, aircrafts or ships, with the exception of mobile customs control equipment;
costs of consumables, including reference or calibration material, for customs control equipment;
costs relating to personal protective equipment.
The instrument may finance up to 80 % of the total eligible costs of an action.
The following costs shall not be eligible for funding under the instrument:
costs related to the purchase of land;
costs relating to training or the upgrading of skills, other than the introductory training included in the purchase or upgrade contract;
costs relating to infrastructure, such as buildings or outdoor facilities, as well as to furniture;
costs associated with electronic systems, with the exception of software and software updates directly necessary to use the customs control equipment and with the exception of the electronic software and programming necessary to interlink existing software with the customs control equipment;
costs of networks, such as secured or unsecured communication channels, or subscriptions, with the exception of networks or subscriptions exclusively necessary to use the customs control equipment;
costs of transport means, such as vehicles, aircrafts or ships, with the exception of mobile customs control equipment;
costs of consumables, including reference or calibration material, for customs control equipment;
costs relating to personal protective equipment.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
The regulation applies from 1 January 2021.

Summary 73:
EU rules on the internal market for electricity
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS DIRECTIVE DO?
It sets out rules for the EU's internal electricity market, which was established in 1996. The aim of this market is to deliver real choice for all EU citizens, new business opportunities, competitive prices, efficient investment signals and higher standards of service, as well as security of supply and sustainability.
KEY POINTS
The internal electricity market
The internal electricity market is based on the principles of free movement of goods, freedom of establishment and freedom to provide services. These freedoms are achievable only in a fully open market, which enables all consumers freely to choose their suppliers and all suppliers freely to deliver to their customers.
The internal market is governed by common rules for the production, supply and distribution of electricity.
The market rules allow for the entry and exit of producers and suppliers based on their assessment of the economic and financial viability of their operations.
Member States retain the right to impose public service obligations in the general economic interest, in accordance with Article 106 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), in particular where supply is severely constrained, causing significantly higher electricity prices than normal, or in the event of a market failure where interventions by regulatory authorities and competition authorities have proven to be ineffective.
Member States must ensure that no undue barriers exist within the internal market for electricity as regards market entry, operation and exit.
The internal market is supported by the European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity (ENTSO-E) and the European Network of Transmission System Operators for Gas (ENTSOG).
Access to the market
The internal market for electricity has been progressively implemented throughout the EU since 1999. It is organised through a competitive electricity market across country borders.
The EU’s energy system is in the middle of a profound change. The common goal of decarbonising the energy system creates new opportunities and challenges for market participants. Technological developments allow for new forms of consumer participation and cross-border cooperation. There is a need to adapt the EU market rules to a new market reality.

Summary 74:
The European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking
The European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking (EuroHPC Joint Undertaking) is established to develop, deploy, extend and maintain in the European Union an integrated world-class supercomputing and data infrastructure and to develop and support a highly competitive and innovative High Performance Computing ecosystem.
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes the EuroHPC Joint Undertaking (EuroHPC Joint Undertaking) to develop, deploy, extend and maintain in the European Union an integrated world-class supercomputing and data infrastructure and to develop and support a highly competitive and innovative High Performance Computing ecosystem.
KEY POINTS
The mission of the EuroHPC Joint Undertaking is to:
develop, deploy, extend and maintain in the European Union an integrated world-class supercomputing and data infrastructure;
develop and support a highly competitive and innovative High Performance Computing ecosystem.
The EuroHPC Joint Undertaking is a public-private partnership between the European Union, the participating Member States and other associated countries, research and industry associations and other organisations with an explicit and active engagement in producing research and innovation results, in developing and deploying high performance computing or quantum computing capabilities, or in contributing to address the skills gap and keep the know-how in the field of high performance computing and quantum computing in Europe.
The EuroHPC Joint Undertaking should address clearly defined topics that would enable academia and European industries at large to design, develop and use the most innovative technologies in high performance computing and quantum computing, and to establish an integrated and federated, secure networked infrastructure across the European Union with world-class high performance computing and quantum computing capability, high-speed connectivity and leading-edge applications and data and software services for its scientists and for other lead users from industry, including small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and the public sector.
The EuroHPC Joint Undertaking should provide financial support in particular in the form of grants and procurement following open and competitive calls for proposals and calls for tenders based on annual work programmes.
The EuroHPC Joint Undertaking should contribute to reducing the specific skills gap across the European Union by engaging in awareness raising measures and assisting in the building of new knowledge and human capital. This includes the design and support of specific educational and training activities in close cooperation with the relevant public and private actors.
The EuroHPC Joint Undertaking should facilitate cooperation between the European Union and international actors by defining a cooperation strategy, including identifying and promoting areas for cooperation in research and development and skills development and implementing actions where there is a mutual benefit, as well as ensuring an access policy of respective high performance computing and quantum computing capabilities and applications mainly based on reciprocity.
The EuroHPC Joint Undertaking should provide a favourable framework for participating Member States to use financial contributions under the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the European Social Fund+, the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund (EMFAF) and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) for the acquisition of high performance computing and quantum computing and data infrastructures and their interconnection.
The EuroHPC Joint Undertaking should provide a favourable framework for participating Member States to use financial contributions under the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) for the acquisition of high performance computing and quantum computing and data infrastructures and their interconnection.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 13 July 2021.

Summary 75:
European Climate Law — EU climate neutrality by 2050
European Climate Law — EU climate neutrality by 2050
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2021/1119 establishing the framework for achieving climate neutrality and amending Regulations (EC) No 401/2009 and (EU) 2018/1999
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes the framework for achieving climate neutrality in the EU by 2050, in pursuit of the long-term temperature goal set out in the Paris Agreement.
It sets a binding target of a net domestic reduction in greenhouse gas emissions for 2030.
KEY POINTS
Climate neutrality
The EU-wide greenhouse gas emissions and removals regulated in EU law must be balanced within the EU by 2050, thus reducing emissions to net zero by that date, and the EU shall aim to achieve negative emissions thereafter.
The relevant EU institutions and the EU Member States must take the necessary measures at EU and national level, respectively, to enable the collective achievement of the climate-neutrality objective set out in the regulation, taking into account the importance of promoting both fairness and solidarity among Member States and cost-effectiveness in achieving this objective.
Scientific advice on climate change
The European Scientific Advisory Board on Climate Change (the Advisory Board) established under Regulation (EC) No 401/2009 serves as a point of reference for the EU on scientific knowledge relating to climate change by virtue of its independence and scientific and technical expertise.
The Advisory Board provides scientific advice and issues reports on existing and proposed EU measures, climate targets and indicative greenhouse gas budgets, and their coherence with the objectives of the regulation and the EU’s international commitments under the Paris Agreement.
The Advisory Board identifies actions and opportunities needed to successfully achieve the EU climate targets and raises awareness on climate change and its impacts, as well as stimulating dialogue and cooperation between scientific bodies within the EU.
The Advisory Board is guided in its work by the best available and most recent scientific evidence, including the latest reports of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).
EU 2030 climate target
The regulation sets a binding EU target of a net domestic reduction in greenhouse gas emissions for 2030.
The regulation also amends Regulation (EU) 2018/1999, which establishes a governance framework for the Energy Union, in order to include the climate-neutrality objective in the relevant provisions of that regulation.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 16 August 2021.
WHAT IS THE REGULATION FOR?
              
It aims to ensure that the EU and its Member States remain on track to achieve the climate-neutrality objective and progress on adaptation.
KEY TERMS
              
Climate neutrality: a state where the anthropogenic emissions by sources and removals by sinks of greenhouse gases regulated in EU law are balanced within the EU, thus reducing emissions to net zero by a given date, and the EU aims to achieve negative emissions thereafter.
MAIN DOCUMENTS
              
Regulation (EU) 2021/1119 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 30 June 2021 establishing the framework for achieving climate neutrality and amending Regulations (EC) No 401/2009 and (EU) 2018/1999 (OJ L 243, 9.7.2021, pp. 1-9).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
              
Regulation (EU) 2018/1999 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 December 2018 on the Governance of the Energy Union and Climate Action (OJ L 334, 19.12.2018, pp. 28-39).
Regulation (EC) No 401/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 24 June 2009 on health, ecologically sound management of the coast and the protection of the maritime environment of the Community (OJ L 152, 15.6.2009, pp. 1-10).

Summary 76:
EU4Health Programme
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the EU4Health Programme (the Programme) for the period 2021–2027.
KEY POINTS
The EU4Health Programme is a means of promoting actions in areas where there is a Union added value that can be demonstrated. Such actions include, inter alia, strengthening the exchange of best practices between Member States, supporting networks for the sharing of knowledge or for mutual learning, addressing cross-border threats to health so as to reduce the risks of such threats and to mitigate their consequences, addressing certain issues relating to the internal market in relation to which the Union can achieve Union-wide high-quality solutions, thereby unlocking the potential of innovation in health, and improving efficiency by avoiding the duplication of activities and optimising the use of financial resources.
The Programme also supports capacity-building actions to strengthen strategic planning, access to multisource financing and the capacity to invest in and implement actions of the Programme. In that respect, the Programme provides country-specific tailor-made assistance to the Member States, or groups of Member States, with the greatest needs.
The Programme is a reinforced programme for Union action in the field of health. It is complementary to the European Health Union (see below).
The Programme supports Union action in the following areas:
preparedness for, and the prevention and control of, the spread of severe human infections and diseases across borders in order to combat other serious cross-border threats to health and to safeguard and improve the health and well-being of all people in the Union;
health emergencies and crisis management;
the production, procurement and management of crisis-relevant products within the Union to mitigate the risk of shortages, while ensuring complementarity with other Union instruments;
the provision of information to individuals, in order to promote disease prevention and healthy lifestyles, to counter misinformation and disinformation as regards the prevention, cause and treatment of diseases, to address vaccine hesitancy and to support efforts to strengthen altruistic behaviour, such as organ and blood donations;
health promotion and disease prevention and improving mental health throughout the lifetime of an individual by addressing health risk factors, and health determinants;
the reduction and prevention of alcohol-related harm, with particular emphasis on protecting the young;
the reduction of the burden of Member States by working together to achieve better and more effective management of chronic diseases;
cancer prevention programmes, in the context of an integrated approach to preventing chronic diseases;
the generation of clinical and real-world evidence to enable the development of, authorisation of, evaluation of and access to effective medicinal products, including generics and biosimilars, to medical devices and to treatment;
the development of a European health data space;
the promotion of research and development with respect to new medicinal products, with particular attention to be given to antimicrobials and vaccines to tackle antimicrobial resistance and vaccine-preventable diseases, respectively;
the promotion of incentives to boost the production capacity for antimicrobials, personalised treatment and vaccination;
the strengthening of decision-making regarding medicinal products by enabling access to and the analysis of real-world healthcare data;
the promotion of the prudent and efficient use of medicinal products, and of antimicrobials in particular, in accordance with the One Health approach;
the development, implementation and enforcement of Union health legislation;
the upscaling of networking through European Reference Networks (ERNs) and other transnational networks;
the development of a Union system for the monitoring, reporting and notification of shortages of medicinal products and medical devices in order to avoid fragmentation of the internal market and to ensure greater availability and affordability of those medicinal products and medical devices while limiting the extent to which their supply chains depend on third countries;
the production of medicinal products and medical devices within the Union;
the development of specific Union preventive and disease management guidelines;

the development of a Union system for the monitoring, reporting and notification of shortages of medicinal products and medical devices in order to avoid fragmentation of the internal market and to ensure greater availability and affordability of those medicinal products and medical devices while limiting the extent to which their supply chains depend on third countries;

Summary 78:
Strategic Innovation Agenda (SIA) of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) 2021-2027
The SIA 2021-2027 sets out the EIT’s priority fields and strategy for the period from 2021 to 2027 (SIA 2021-2027). It establishes the EIT’s key actions, mode of operation, expected results and impact, as well as an estimate of the financial needs and sources for the future activities of the EIT. The SIA 2021-2027 ensures the necessary consistency of the EIT with Horizon Europe.
The SIA 2021-2027 is informed by an impact assessment carried out by the Commission. It takes into account the draft SIA prepared by the EIT and submitted to the Commission on 20 December 2017, in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 294/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council (1). It also reflects Regulation (EU) 2021/695, and, in particular, the key role of the EIT as part of Pillar III ‘Innovative Europe’ of Horizon Europe, and its contribution to addressing global and societal challenges, including established targets and commitments to climate objectives and the United Nations (UN) Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and to Pillar I ‘Excellent Science’ and Pillar II ‘Global Challenges and European Industrial Competitiveness’ of Horizon Europe. The SIA 2021-2027 builds on the lessons learnt over the previous years of operation of the EIT and the results of a wide consultation process with key stakeholders.
The SIA 2021-2027 takes into account the strategic planning of Horizon Europe to ensure consistency with the Horizon Europe activities, as well as synergies with other relevant Union programmes and consistency with Union priorities and commitments, including those related to the European Green Deal, the Recovery Plan for Europe, the European strategy for data, the SME Strategy for a sustainable and digital Europe and the New Industrial Strategy for Europe and those related to achieving the Union’s strategic autonomy, while retaining an open economy. Furthermore, it contributes to tackling global and societal challenges, including the SDGs by following the principles of the Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (2), and to achieving a net-zero greenhouse gas economy by 2050 at the latest. It also aims to increase complementarity and synergies between the EIT activities and national and regional funding programmes and priorities.
The SIA 2021-2027 sets out the EIT’s key actions, mode of operation, expected results and impact, as well as an estimate of the financial needs and sources for the future activities of the EIT. It also includes an indicative financial plan covering the period of the relevant multiannual financial framework (MFF).
The SIA 2021-2027 ensures the continuity of the activities of the EIT and the Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs) in compliance with the relevant provisions of Regulation (EU) 2021/695.
In order to ensure the continuity of the activities of the EIT and the KICs in compliance with the relevant provisions of Regulation (EU) 2021/695, this Decision enters into force as a matter of urgency and applies, with retroactive effect, from 1 January 2021.

Summary 79:
EU rules on the definition, description, presentation and labelling of aromatised wine products and on the protection of geographical indications of aromatised wine products
EU rules on the definition, description, presentation and labelling of aromatised wine products and on the protection of geographical indications of aromatised wine products
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It lays down rules on the definition, description, presentation and labelling of aromatised wine products (AWP) and rules on the protection of geographical indications of AWP.
It repeals Regulation (EEC) No 1601/91.
KEY POINTS
Definition and classification of AWP
AWP are classified into the following categories:
aromatised wines,
aromatised wine-based drinks,
aromatised wine-product cocktails.
Aromatised wine is a drink:
obtained from one or more of the grapevine products defined in Annex II to Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013,
in which the grapevine products referred to in point (a) represent at least 75 % of the total volume,
to which alcohol may have been added,
to which colours may have been added,
to which grape must, partially fermented grape must or both may have been added,
which may have been sweetened,
which has an actual alcoholic strength by volume of not less than 14,5 % vol. and less than 22 % vol. and a total alcoholic strength by volume of not less than 17,5 % vol.
Aromatised wine-based drink is a drink:
obtained from one or more of the grapevine products defined in points 1, 2 and 4 to 9 of Annex II to Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013,
in which the grapevine products referred to in point (a) represent at least 50 % of the total volume,
to which no alcohol has been added,
to which colours may have been added,
to which grape must, partially fermented grape must or both may have been added,
which may have been sweetened,
which has an actual alcoholic strength by volume of not less than 4,5 % vol. and less than 14,5 % vol.
Aromatised wine-product cocktail is a drink:
obtained from one or more of the grapevine products defined in points 1, 2 and 4 to 11 of Annex II to Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013,
in which the grapevine products referred to in point (a) represent at least 50 % of the total volume,
to which no alcohol has been added,
to which colours may have been added,
which may have been sweetened,
which has an actual alcoholic strength by volume of more than 1,2 % vol. and less than 10 % vol.
Production processes and methods of analysis for AWP
AWP shall be produced in accordance with the requirements, restrictions and descriptions laid down in Annexes I and II.
The Commission shall be empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 33 concerning the establishment of authorised production processes for obtaining AWP, taking into account consumers’ expectations.
Sales denominations
The sales denominations set out in Annex II shall be used for any AWP placed on the market in the EU, provided that it complies with the requirements for the corresponding sales denomination laid down in that Annex.
Sales denominations may be supplemented by a customary name as defined in Article 2(2)(o) of Regulation (EU) No 1169/2013.
Where AWP comply with the requirements of more than one sales denomination, the use of only one of those sales denominations is authorised, except where Annex II provides otherwise.
An alcoholic beverage not fulfilling the requirements laid down in this Regulation shall not be described, presented or labelled by associating words or phrases such as ‘like’, ‘type’, ‘style’, ‘made’, ‘flavour’ or any other term similar to any of the sales denominations.
Sales denominations may be supplemented or replaced by a geographical indication protected under this Regulation.
Additional particulars to the sales denominations
The sales denominations referred to in Article 5 may also be supplemented by the following particulars concerning the sugar content of the AWP:
‘extra-dry’: in the case of products with a sugar content of less than 30 grams per litre and, for the category of aromatised wines and by way of derogation from Article 3(2)(g), a minimum total alcoholic strength by volume of 15 % vol.;
‘dry’: in the case of products with a sugar content of less than 50 grams per litre and, for the category of aromatised wines and by way of derogation from Article 3(2)(g), a minimum total alcoholic strength by volume of 16 % vol.;
‘semi-dry’: in the case of products with a sugar content of between 50 and less than 90 grams per litre;
‘semi-sweet’: in the case of products with a sugar content of between 90 and less than 130 grams per litre;
‘sweet’: in the case of products with a sugar content of 130 grams per litre or more.
The sugar content indicated in points (a) to (e) of the first subparagraph is expressed as invert sugar.
The particulars ‘semi-sweet’ and ‘sweet’ may be accompanied by an indication of the sugar content, expressed in grams of invert sugar per litre.
Sales denominations may also be supplemented by a reference to the main flavouring used.
Geographical indications
To be eligible for a geographical indication protected under this Regulation, a product shall comply with the corresponding product specification which shall include at least:
the name to be protected,
a description of the product, in particular its principal analytical characteristics as well as an indication of its organoleptic characteristics,
where applicable, the particular production processes and specifications as well as the relevant restrictions on making the product,
the demarcation of the geographical area concerned,
the details bearing out the link referred to in point (3) of Article 2,
the applicable requirements laid down in Union or national law or, where provided for by Member States, by an organisation which manages the protected geographical indication, having regard to the fact that such requirements shall be objective, and non-discriminatory and compatible with Union law,
an indication of the main raw material from which the AWP is obtained,
the name and address of the authorities or bodies verifying compliance with the provisions of the product specification and their specific tasks.
FROM WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 28 March 2015.

Summary 80:
EU fishing opportunities for 2020
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2020/123 — fixing for 2020 the fishing opportunities for certain fish stocks and groups of fish stocks, applicable in Union waters and, for Union fishing vessels, in certain non-Union waters
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It sets fishing opportunities for certain fish stocks and groups of fish stocks for 2020, applicable in Union waters and, for Union fishing vessels, in certain non-Union waters.
It applies to the following vessels:
Union fishing vessels;
third-country vessels in Union waters.
It also applies to recreational fisheries where such fisheries are expressly referred to in its relevant provisions.
KEY POINTS
The regulation fixes:
catch limits for 2020 and, where specified in the regulation, for 2021;
fishing effort limits for 2020;
fishing opportunities for certain stocks in the CCAMLR Convention Area for the period from 1 December 2019 to 30 November 2020;
fishing opportunities for certain stocks in the IATTC Convention Area set out in Article 30 for the periods in 2019 and 2020 specified in that Article.
The regulation applies to the following vessels:
Union fishing vessels;
third-country vessels in Union waters.
It also applies to recreational fisheries where such fisheries are expressly referred to in its relevant provisions.
The regulation sets out the fishing opportunities for certain fish stocks and groups of fish stocks for 2020, applicable in Union waters and, for Union fishing vessels, in certain non-Union waters.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 1 January 2020, except for the provisions concerning fishing effort limits, which apply from 1 February 2020, and certain provisions concerning particular regions, which apply from 1 July 2020.
The regulation entered into force on 30 January 2020.
BACKGROUND
The Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) aims to ensure that the Union’s fishing fleet operates in a sustainable way and that the Union’s fish stocks are managed in a responsible manner. To this end, the CFP provides for annual negotiations between the European Commission and the EU countries on the fishing opportunities for certain fish stocks and groups of fish stocks, applicable in EU waters and, for EU vessels, in certain non-EU waters.
For 2020, the Commission proposed a set of fishing opportunities for certain fish stocks and groups of fish stocks. The EU countries then negotiated these proposals with the Commission and reached agreement on the final package.
For more information, see the EU fishing policy on the European Commission's website.
KEY TERMS
Union fishing vessel: a fishing vessel flying the flag of, and registered in, an EU country.
FROM WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 1 January 2020, except for the provisions concerning fishing effort limits, which apply from 1 February 2020, and certain provisions concerning particular regions, which apply from 1 July 2020.
It entered into force on 30 January 2020.

EU macro-financial assistance to Ukraine
EU macro-financial assistance to Ukraine
SUMMARY OF:
Decision (EU) 2022/313 on providing macro-financial assistance to Ukraine
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION?
It provides macro-financial assistance (MFA) to Ukraine of up to €1.2 billion, with a view to supporting the country’s economic stabilisation and substantive reform agenda.
KEY POINTS
The MFA is subject to the approval of the Union budget by the European Parliament and the Council.
The MFA is to be disbursed in 2 equal instalments. The Commission is to decide on the release of the instalments, subject to the fulfilment of the following conditions:
respect for democracy, the rule of law, human rights and effective democratic mechanisms;
continuous satisfactory track record of implementing a non-precautionary IMF credit arrangement;
satisfactory implementation of the economic policy and financial conditions agreed in the memorandum of understanding (MOU).
The MOU sets out the conditions for the MFA, which are consistent with the agreements or understandings reached between the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and Ukraine, and with the key principles and objectives of economic reforms set out in the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, including the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA).
The MFA is to be disbursed to the National Bank of Ukraine. Subject to the provisions to be agreed in the MOU, including a confirmation of residual budgetary financing needs, the Union funds may be transferred to the Ukrainian Ministry of Finance as the final beneficiary.
The Commission is to regularly inform the European Parliament and the Council of developments regarding the MFA, including disbursements thereof, and is to provide those institutions with the relevant documents in due time.
The MFA is to be made available for a period of 12 months, starting on the first day after the entry into force of the MOU.
The MFA is to be disbursed in 2 equal instalments, each of which is to consist of a loan.
The Commission is empowered to borrow the necessary funds on the capital markets or from financial institutions and to on-lend them to Ukraine.
The MFA is to be disbursed in 2 equal instalments, each of which is to consist of a loan.
The detailed financial terms of the MFA are to be laid down in a loan agreement to be concluded between the Commission and Ukraine.
The Commission is empowered to negotiate the economic policy and financial conditions, including a timeframe for the fulfilment of those conditions, with the Ukrainian authorities.
The conditions are to aim, in particular, to enhance the efficiency, transparency and accountability of the public finance management systems in Ukraine, including for the use of the MFA. Progress in mutual market opening, the development of rule-based and fair trade, and other priorities in the context of the EU’s external policy are to be duly taken into account when designing the policy measures.
The Commission is to regularly monitor the progress in attaining those objectives.
The Commission and the European External Action Service are to monitor the fulfilment of the precondition set out in Article 2(1) throughout the life-cycle of the MFA.

satisfactory implementation of the economic policy and financial conditions agreed in the MOU.
The conditions referred to in Article 4(3) are to continue to be met, including whether the economic policies of Ukraine are in accordance with the objectives of the MFA. Summary 82:
A multiannual recovery plan for Mediterranean swordfish and the deletion of certain provisions from Regulation (EU) 2017/2107
A multiannual recovery plan for Mediterranean swordfish and the deletion of certain provisions from Regulation (EU) 2017/2107
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2019/1154 on a multiannual recovery plan for Mediterranean swordfish and amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1967/2006 and Regulation (EU) 2017/2107 of the European Parliament and of the Council
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes a multiannual recovery plan for swordfish (Xiphias gladius) in the Mediterranean Sea (‘Mediterranean swordfish’).
It amends Council Regulation (EC) No 1967/2006 and Regulation (EU) 2017/2107 of the European Parliament and of the Council.
KEY POINTS
Subject matter and scope
The regulation applies to:
Union fishing vessels, and Union vessels engaged in recreational fishing, which:
catch Mediterranean swordfish;
tranship or carry on board, including outside the ICCAT Convention area, Mediterranean swordfish;
third country fishing vessels, and third country vessels engaged in recreational fisheries, which operate in Union waters and which catch Mediterranean swordfish;
third country vessels which are inspected in Member States ports and which carry on board Mediterranean swordfish or fishery products originating from Mediterranean swordfish that have not been previously landed or transhipped at ports.
Management measures
Each Member State takes the necessary measures to ensure that the fishing effort of fishing vessels flying its flag is commensurate with the fishing opportunities for Mediterranean swordfish available to that Member State.
Each Member State allocates fishing opportunities for Mediterranean swordfish in accordance with the requirements of Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013.
Member States limit the number of fishing vessels flying their flag and authorised to catch Mediterranean swordfish to the average yearly number of vessels flying their flag that fished for, retained on board, transhipped, transported or landed Mediterranean swordfish during the period 2013-2016.
Each Member State submits its annual fishing plans to the Commission by 1 March of each year. Such annual fishing plans shall include detailed information regarding the quota for Mediterranean swordfish allocated by fishing gear type, including quota allocated to recreational fisheries, where relevant, and to by-catches.
Technical conservation measures
Mediterranean swordfish shall not be caught, either as targeted species or as by-catch, retained on board, transhipped or landed during the closure period. The closure period shall be from 1 January to 31 March of each year.
By way of derogation from Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013, it shall be prohibited to catch, retain on board, tranship, land, transport, store, sell or display or offer for sale Mediterranean swordfish, including in recreational fisheries:
measuring less than 100 cm lower jaw to fork length (LJFL); or
weighing less than 11,4 kg of live weight, or 10,2 kg of gilled and gutted weight.
Only entire specimens of Mediterranean swordfish, without removal of any external part, or gilled and gutted specimens, may be retained on board, transhipped landed or carried in the first transport after landing.
Notwithstanding Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013, fishing vessels targeting Mediterranean swordfish may retain on board, tranship, transfer, land, transport, store, sell or display or offer for sale incidental catches of Mediterranean swordfish below the minimum conservation reference size, provided such catches do not exceed 5 % by weight or number of specimens of the total Mediterranean swordfish catch of the fishing vessels concerned.
By-catches of Mediterranean swordfish shall not exceed at any time following a fishing operation the by-catch limit that Member States establish in their annual fishing plans for the total catch on board by weight or number of specimens.
Where the quota for Mediterranean swordfish allocated to the flag Member State is exhausted, any Mediterranean swordfish caught alive shall be released.
The maximum number of hooks that may be set by or carried on board fishing vessels targeting Mediterranean swordfish shall be fixed at 2 500 hooks.
The hook size shall not be smaller than 7 cm in height.
The length of the pelagic longlines shall not exceed 30 nautical miles (55,56 km).
Control measures
Member States shall issue fishing authorisations to fishing vessels targeting Mediterranean swordfish and flying their flag, in accordance with the relevant provisions laid down in Regulation (EU) 2017/2403, in particular Articles 20 and 21 thereof.
Only Union vessels included in the ICCAT record of vessels, in accordance with the procedure laid down in Articles 16 and 17, shall be allowed to target, retain on board, tranship, land, transport or process Mediterranean swordfish, without prejudice to the provisions on by-catches laid down in Article 13.
Each Member State with a quota for Mediterranean swordfish shall implement a national scientific observer programme for pelagic longline vessels flying that Member State's flag and targeting Mediterranean swordfish in accordance with this Article. The national observer programme shall comply with the minimum standards laid down in Annex I.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2019.

Multiannual financial framework 2014–20
The European Union (EU) has set up a multiannual financial framework for the period 2014–20. The aim is to ensure the continuity of EU policies and programmes.
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets up the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014–20. The aim is to ensure the continuity of EU policies and programmes.
KEY POINTS

Summary 84:
European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund (EMFAF) for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027.
KEY POINTS
The EMFAF has a budget of EUR 6.1 billion for 7 years. It is split between shared and direct management (EUR 5.3 billion and EUR 0.8 billion respectively).
The EMFAF aims to support the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), the Union’s maritime policy and the Union’s international commitments in the field of ocean governance. It is a key enabler for sustainable fisheries and the conservation of marine biological resources, for food security through the supply of seafood products, for the growth of a sustainable blue economy and for healthy, safe, secure, clean and sustainably managed seas and oceans.
The EMFAF provides support for:
fostering sustainable fisheries and the restoration and conservation of aquatic biological resources;
fostering sustainable aquaculture activities, and processing and marketing of fishery and aquaculture products, thus contributing to food security in the Union;
enabling a sustainable blue economy in coastal, island and inland areas, and fostering the development of fishing and aquaculture communities;
strengthening international ocean governance and enabling seas and oceans to be safe, secure, clean and sustainably managed.
The EMFAF is based on 4 priorities. Member States, in their programmes, indicate the most appropriate means for achieving these priorities.
The EMFAF provides support for:
avoiding and reducing, as far as possible, unwanted catches and of minimising the negative impact of fishing activities on the marine ecosystem;
achieving a 30 % target of all expenditure under the MFF 2021-2027 spent on mainstreaming climate objectives and contributing to the ambition of providing 7.5 % of annual spending under the MFF 2021-2027 to biodiversity objectives in 2024 and 10 % of annual spending under the MFF 2021-2027 to biodiversity objectives in 2026 and 2027, while considering the existing overlaps between climate and biodiversity goals;
avoiding and reducing, as far as possible, the impact of fishing activities on the marine environment;
avoiding and reducing, as far as possible, the impact of maritime activities on the marine environment;
supporting the promotion of clean and healthy seas and the implementation of the European strategy for plastics in a circular economy;
achieving the environmental, economic, social and employment objectives of the CFP, as set out in Article 2 of Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013.
The EMFAF provides support for:
fostering sustainable fisheries and the restoration and conservation of aquatic biological resources;
fostering sustainable aquaculture activities, and processing and marketing of fishery and aquaculture products, thus contributing to food security in the Union;
enabling a sustainable blue economy in coastal, island and inland areas, and fostering the development of fishing and aquaculture communities;
strengthening international ocean governance and enabling seas and oceans to be safe, secure, clean and sustainably managed.
The EMFAF provides support for:
