Summary 157:
European Regional Development Fund (ERDF)
European Regional Development Fund (ERDF)
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the specific provisions of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) for the 2014-2020 period.
It sets out the investment priorities within the thematic objectives of the Investment for Growth and Jobs goal to which the ERDF may contribute.
KEY POINTS
The ERDF aims to reinforce economic, social and territorial cohesion by redressing the main regional imbalances in the European Union (EU) through the sustainable development and structural adjustment of regional economies.
The ERDF may support the following activities:
productive investment which creates and safeguards sustainable jobs through direct aid for investment in small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs);
productive investment which contributes to the investment priorities set out in this regulation and, where that investment involves cooperation between large enterprises and SMEs, in the priority to support SMEs;
investment in infrastructure providing basic services to citizens in the areas of energy, environment, transport and information and communication technologies;
investment in social, health, research, innovation, business and educational infrastructure;
investment in the development of endogenous potential through fixed investment in equipment and small-scale infrastructure, including small-scale cultural and sustainable tourism infrastructure, support to research and innovation bodies and investment in technology and applied research in enterprises;
networking, cooperation and exchange of experience between competent regional, local, urban and other public authorities, economic and social partners and relevant bodies representing civil society, studies, preparatory actions and capacity-building.
The ERDF may also support the sharing of facilities and human resources, and all types of infrastructure across borders in all regions.
The ERDF may not support:
the decommissioning or the construction of nuclear power stations;
investment to achieve the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from activities listed in Annex I to Directive 2003/87/EC;
the manufacturing, processing and marketing of tobacco and tobacco products;
undertakings in difficulty, as defined under EU State aid rules;
investment in airport infrastructure unless related to environmental protection or accompanied by investment necessary to mitigate or reduce its negative environmental impact.
The thematic objectives set out in the first paragraph of Article 9 of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 and the corresponding investment priorities set out in this regulation to which the ERDF may contribute under the Investment for growth and jobs goal shall be concentrated as follows:
in more developed regions:
at least 80 % of the total ERDF resources at national level shall be allocated to two or more of the thematic objectives set out in points 1, 2, 3 and 4 of the first paragraph of Article 9 of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013;
at least 20 % of the total ERDF resources at national level shall be allocated to the thematic objective set out in point 4 of the first paragraph of Article 9 of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013;
in transition regions:
at least 60 % of the total ERDF resources at national level shall be allocated to two or more of the thematic objectives set out in points 1, 2, 3 and 4 of the first paragraph of Article 9 of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013;
at least 15 % of the total ERDF resources at national level shall be allocated to the thematic objective set out in point 4 of the first paragraph of Article 9 of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013;
in less developed regions:
at least 50 % of the total ERDF resources at national level shall be allocated to two or more of the thematic objectives set in out in points 1, 2, 3 and 4 of the first paragraph of Article 9 of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013;
at least 12 % of the total ERDF resources at national level shall be allocated to the thematic objective set out in point 4 of the first paragraph of Article 9 of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013.
The ERDF shall support the following investment priorities within the thematic objectives set out in the first paragraph of Article 9 of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013:
strengthening research, technological development and innovation by:
enhancing research and innovation (R&I) infrastructure and capacities to develop R&I excellence, and promoting centres of competence, in particular those of European interest;
promoting business investment in R&I, developing links and synergies between enterprises, research and development centres and the higher education sector, in particular promoting investment in product and service development, technology transfer, social innovation, eco-innovation, public service applications, demand stimulation, networking, clusters and open innovation through smart specialisation, and supporting technological and applied research, pilot lines, early product validation actions, advanced manufacturing capabilities and first production, in particular in key enabling technologies and diffusion of general purpose technologies;
enhancing access to, and use and quality of, ICT by:
extending broadband deployment and the roll-out of high-speed networks and supporting the adoption of emerging technologies and networks for the digital economy;
developing ICT products and services, e-commerce, and enhancing demand for ICT;
strengthening ICT applications for e-government, e-learning, e-inclusion, e-culture and e-health;
enhancing the competitiveness of SMEs by:
promoting entrepreneurship, in particular by facilitating the economic exploitation of new ideas and fostering the creation of new firms, including through business incubators;
developing and implementing new business models for SMEs, in particular with regard to internationalisation;
supporting the creation and the extension of advanced capacities for product and service development;
supporting the capacity of SMEs to grow in regional, national and international markets, and to engage in innovation processes;
supporting the shift towards a low-carbon economy in all sectors by:
promoting the production and distribution of energy derived from renewable sources;
promoting energy efficiency and renewable energy use in enterprises;
supporting energy efficiency, smart energy management and renewable energy use in public infrastructure, including in public buildings, and in the housing sector;
developing and implementing smart distribution systems that operate at low and medium voltage levels;
promoting low-carbon strategies for all types of territories, in particular for urban areas, including the promotion of sustainable multimodal urban mobility and mitigation-relevant adaptation measures;
promoting research and innovation in, and adoption of, low-carbon technologies;
promoting the use of high-efficiency co-generation of heat and power based on useful heat demand;
promoting climate change adaptation, risk prevention and management by:
supporting investment for adaptation to climate change, including ecosystem-based approaches;
promoting investment to address specific risks, ensuring disaster resilience and developing disaster management systems;
preserving and protecting the environment and promoting resource efficiency by:
investing in the waste sector to meet the requirements of the Union's environmental acquis and to address needs, identified by the Member States, for investment that goes beyond those requirements;
investing in the water sector to meet the requirements of the Union's environmental acquis and to address needs, identified by the Member States, for investment that goes beyond those requirements;
conserving, protecting, promoting and developing natural and cultural heritage;
protecting and restoring biodiversity and soil and promoting ecosystem services, including through Natura 2000, and green infrastructure;
taking action to



Summary 158:
Specific provisions for the support from the European Regional Development Fund to the European territorial cooperation goal
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 1299/2013 on specific provisions for the support from the European Regional Development Fund to the European territorial cooperation goal
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes the scope of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) with regard to the European territorial cooperation goal and lays down specific provisions concerning that goal.
KEY POINTS
The ERDF supports 3 types of cooperation:
cross-border cooperation between adjacent regions to promote integrated regional development between neighbouring land and maritime border regions in 2 or more EU countries or between neighbouring border regions in at least 1 EU country and 1 third country on external borders of the EU;
transnational cooperation over larger transnational territories, involving national, regional and local partners and also covering maritime cross-border cooperation in cases not covered by cross-border cooperation, with a view to achieving a higher degree of territorial integration of those territories;
interregional cooperation to reinforce the effectiveness of cohesion policy by promoting:
exchange of experience focusing on thematic objectives among partners throughout the EU, including in relation to the development of regions referred to in Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) on the identification and dissemination of good practices with a view to their transfer principally to operational programmes under the Investment for growth and jobs goal but also, where relevant, to cooperation programmes;
exchange of experience concerning the identification, transfer and dissemination of good practices and innovative approaches in relation to the implementation of cooperation programmes and actions as well as to the use of European groupings of territorial cooperation (EGTCs);
analysis of development trends in relation to the aims of territorial cohesion, including territorial aspects of economic and social cohesion, and harmonious development of Union territory through studies, data collection and other measures.
The resources for the European territorial cooperation goal amount to 2.75% of the global resources available for budgetary commitment from the ERDF, European Social Fund (ESF) and the Cohesion Fund for the 2014-2020 programming period and set out in Article 91(1) of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 (i.e., a total of EUR 19.5 billion).

Summary 159:
Guidelines for trans-European energy infrastructure
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 347/2013 on guidelines for trans-European energy infrastructure and repealing Decision No 1364/2006/EC and amending Regulations (EC) No 713/2009, (EC) No 714/2009 and (EC) No 715/2009
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It lays down guidelines for the timely development and interoperability of priority corridors and areas of trans-European energy infrastructure.
The regulation establishes 12 regional groups of countries that are responsible for identifying projects of common interest (POCI) necessary to implement priority corridors and areas falling under the energy infrastructure categories in electricity, gas, oil, and carbon dioxide.
KEY POINTS
Projects of common interest (POCI)
Projects of common interest (POCI) are defined as those necessary to implement the energy infrastructure priority corridors and areas set out in Annex I to the regulation. They are identified by the 12 regional groups of countries established by the regulation, and each group adopts a regional list of proposed POCI. These are then assessed by the Commission and, if they fulfil the criteria set out in Article 4 of the regulation, they are included in the Union list of POCI.
The regulation establishes 12 regional groups of countries that are responsible for identifying projects of common interest (POCI) necessary to implement priority corridors and areas falling under the energy infrastructure categories in electricity, gas, oil, and carbon dioxide.
The first Union list of POCI was adopted in 2014 and includes 246 projects. The second Union list of POCI, adopted in 2016, includes 283 projects.
The regulation establishes 12 regional groups of countries that are responsible for identifying projects of common interest (POCI) necessary to implement priority corridors and areas falling under the energy infrastructure categories in electricity, gas, oil, and carbon dioxide.

Summary 160:
Online dispute resolution
Online dispute resolution
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 524/2013 on online dispute resolution for consumer disputes and amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Directive 2009/22/EC
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
              
It aims to set up a European online dispute resolution (ODR) platform for online disputes governed by common rules.
KEY POINTS
              
The ODR platform is a single point of entry for consumers and traders seeking the out-of-court resolution of disputes covered by the regulation.
The ODR platform offers an electronic complaint form, which can be filled in by the complainant party in accordance with Article 8 of the regulation. The complaint form is user-friendly and easily accessible on the ODR platform.
The information to be submitted by the complainant party is listed in the annex to the regulation. That information is sufficient to determine the competent ADR entity. The complainant party may attach documents in support of the complaint.
The Commission may adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 17 of the regulation to adapt the information listed in the annex to the regulation.
The Commission shall lay down the rules concerning the modalities for the electronic complaint form by means of implementing acts.
The ODR platform shall transmit the complaint to the ADR entity, which the parties have agreed to use, in accordance with Article 9 of the regulation.
The ODR platform shall offer an electronic case management tool free of charge, which enables the parties and the ADR entity to conduct the dispute resolution procedure online through the ODR platform.
The ODR platform shall provide an electronic form by means of which ADR entities shall transmit the information referred to in point (c) of Article 10 of the regulation.
The ODR platform shall make publicly available the following:
general information on ADR as a means of out-of-court dispute resolution;
information on ADR entities listed in accordance with Article 20(2) of Directive 2013/11/EU which are competent to deal with disputes covered by the regulation;
an online guide about how to submit complaints through the ODR platform;
information, including contact details, on ODR contact points designated by the Member States in accordance with Article 7(1) of the regulation.
The ODR platform shall provide a feedback system which allows the parties to express their views on the functioning of the ODR platform and on the ADR entity which has handled their dispute.
The ODR platform shall make publicly available statistical data on the outcome of the disputes which were transmitted to ADR entities through the ODR platform.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 9 January 2016.

Summary 161:
Direct payments to farmers
Direct payments to farmers
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013 establishing rules for direct payments to farmers under support schemes within the framework of the common agricultural policy (CAP)
Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 from the European Parliament and the Council establishing uniform supported for farmers within the framework of the CAP
WHAT IS THE AIMS OF THE REGULATIONS?
Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013 repeals Regulation (EC) No 73/2009 and replaces it with a new text.
Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 repeals Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 and Regulation (EC) No 637/2008 and replaces them with a new text.
The purpose of both regulations is to reform the common agricultural policy (CAP) in order to ensure that it is better targeted and more effective.
Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013 lays down the rules for direct payments to farmers under support schemes within the framework of the CAP. It applies from 1 January 2014.
KEY POINTS
Eligible farmers
Farmers are eligible for direct payments if they:
have a permanent operating basis and have been active in agriculture during the reference period (the year preceding the year in which the payment is due);
fulfil the conditions for good agricultural and environmental condition and good results in the cross-compliance control system;
are not subject to any exclusion or administrative penalty under Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013.
Direct payments
Farmers may receive 2 types of direct payments:
basic payment: this is a payment made per hectare of land that is eligible for support and that a farmer has in his/her holding;
premium: this is a payment made to farmers who comply with the specific rules of the sector-specific support schemes (see Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013).
Basic payment
Farmers may receive a basic payment if they:
are eligible for direct payments;
have a permanent operating basis;
have a land area of 2 hectares or more.
The basic payment is calculated on the basis of the number of payment entitlements that a farmer holds and the value of those entitlements.
Payment entitlements
A payment entitlement is an instrument that allows a farmer to receive the basic payment for a certain number of hectares. A farmer can hold payment entitlements by virtue of:
owning land;
leasing land;
having a share in a partnership.
A farmer may hold several payment entitlements, but the total number of payment entitlements held may not exceed the number of hectares of land he/she has.
The value of the payment entitlements determines the amount of the basic payment received by the farmer.
The basic payment may be granted to farmers who:
have inherited or acquired a holding;
have leased a holding;
are the beneficiary of an inheritance contract.
Single area payment scheme
Farmers in the following EU countries may apply the single area payment scheme until 31 December 2020:
Cyprus;
Greece;
Italy;
Latvia;
Lithuania;
Portugal;
Romania;
Slovenia.
For these countries, the basic payment may be granted to farmers who:
have a permanent operating basis;
have a land area of 2 hectares or more;
have been active in agriculture during the reference period.
Premium
Farmers may receive a premium if they:
have a permanent operating basis;
have been active in agriculture during the reference period;
fulfil the conditions for good agricultural and environmental condition and good results in the cross-compliance control system;
are not subject to any exclusion or administrative penalty under Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013.
The premium may be granted to farmers who:
have inherited or acquired a holding;
have leased a holding;
are the beneficiary of an inheritance contract.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013 applies from 1 January 2014.
REFERENCES

KEY TERMS
Agricultural area: the total area of land and water used by a farmer for agricultural production. It includes the area of land and water used for the production of crops and livestock, the production of livestock products, the production of livestock by-products, the rearing of livestock and the rearing of game animals.
Permanent operating basis: a permanent operating basis is a land area, including buildings, necessary for the agricultural activity of the holding.

Summary 162:
EU support for small islands in the Aegean Sea
EU support for small islands in the Aegean Sea
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 229/2013 laying down specific measures for agriculture in favour of the smaller Aegean islands and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1405/2006
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes specific measures for agriculture in favour of the smaller Aegean islands to mitigate the difficulties caused by the particular geographical situation of the smaller Aegean islands.
KEY POINTS
The specific measures provided for in the regulation are defined by a support programme comprising:
specific supply arrangements;
specific measures to assist local agricultural production.
The support programme is established at the geographical level deemed most appropriate by Greece.
The specific supply arrangements are established for the Union’s agricultural products which are essential in the smaller islands for human consumption, for the manufacture of other products or as agricultural inputs.
The aid granted to supply the smaller islands with agricultural products is determined for each product concerned, taking account of the additional costs of marketing products in the smaller islands, calculated from the usual ports of shipment in mainland Greece, and from the ports of islands of transit or of loading for the islands of final destination. In the case of agricultural inputs and products intended for processing, such aid should take account of the additional costs associated with insularity, small size and distance from markets.
The specific supply arrangements only apply to products of sound, fair and marketable quality.
In implementing the specific supply arrangements, account is taken, in particular, of the following:
the specific needs of the smaller islands and the precise quality requirements;
traditional trade flows with ports in mainland Greece and between the islands in the Aegean Sea;
the economic aspect of the proposed aid;
where applicable, the need not to obstruct the development of local products.
In implementing the specific supply arrangements, the aid granted is subject to the condition that the impact of the economic advantage is passed on up to the end-user who, as appropriate, may be the consumer in the case of products meant for direct consumption, the end processor or packager in the case of products meant for the processing or packaging industries, or farmers in the case of products used for animal feed or as agricultural inputs.
The aid provided for in Article 9(1) is granted on presentation of a certificate.
The aid provided for in the regulation is financed under the financial allocation referred to in Article 18(2) and (3). The support programme comprises a forecast supply balance indicating the products, the quantities thereof and the amount of aid for supply from the Union together with a draft programme of support for local production.
The Commission may authorise, in accordance with Article 108 of the Treaty, operating aid in the sectors producing, processing, marketing and transporting the agricultural products covered by Annex I to the Treaty, with a view to alleviating the specific constraints on farming in the smaller islands as a result of their insularity, small size, mountainous terrain and climate, their economic dependency on a small number of products and their distance from markets.
The Union shall finance the measures provided for in Chapters III and IV up to a maximum annual amount of EUR 23,93 million.
The Commission shall adopt implementing acts establishing the requirements in accordance with which Greece may amend the allocation of resources allocated each year to the various products benefiting from the specific supply arrangements.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 21 March 2013.

Summary 163:
Road transport statistics
Road transport statistics
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 70/2012 on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road (recast)
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It lays down the rules for the compilation of statistics on the carriage of goods by road by means of vehicles registered in the EU.
The Commission has delegated and implementing powers to adopt acts to update Annex I of the Regulation, except for any modifications to the optional nature of the required information, and to adapt Annexes II to VII to take account of economic and technical developments.
KEY POINTS
Road transport vehicles
A road transport vehicle is a road vehicle fitted with an engine whence it derives its sole means of propulsion, which is normally used for carrying persons or goods by road, or for drawing, on the road, vehicles used for the carriage of persons or goods.
A goods road transport vehicle is any single road transport vehicle, or combination of road vehicles, namely road train or articulated vehicle designed to carry goods.
A lorry is a rigid road vehicle designed exclusively or primarily to carry goods.
A road tractor is a road transport vehicle designed exclusively or primarily to haul other road vehicles which are not power-driven (mainly semi-trailers).
A trailer is a road vehicle for the transport of goods with no front axle so designed that part of the vehicle and a substantial part of its loaded weight rest on the road tractor.
A semi-trailer is a road vehicle for the transport of goods with no front axle so designed that part of the vehicle and a substantial part of its loaded weight rest on the road tractor.
An articulated vehicle is a road tractor coupled to a semi-trailer.
A road train is a goods road transport vehicle coupled to a trailer or an articulated vehicle with a further trailer attached.
A vehicle is registered when it is entered in a register of road transport vehicles, kept by an official body in a Member State, whether or not the registration is accompanied by the issue of a registration plate.
Data collection
Each Member State shall compile statistics for the Union on the carriage of goods by road by means of goods road transport vehicles which are registered in that Member State, and on the journeys made by such vehicles.
The statistical variables in each area, their definition and the levels within the classification used for their breakdown are set out in Annexes II to VII.
Member States shall transmit to the European Statistical System Committee (ESSC) every quarter duly verified individual data corresponding to the variables referred to in Article 3 and listed in Annex I, without indicating the name, address or registration number.
The Commission shall be empowered to adopt, where necessary, delegated acts in accordance with Article 8 concerning the updating of Part 1 of Annex I, solely in order to take account of economic and technical developments, except for any modifications to the optional nature of the required information.
The Commission shall be empowered to adopt, where necessary, implementing acts in accordance with Article 9 concerning the adaptation of Annexes II to VII to take account of economic and technical developments.
The Commission shall be empowered to adopt, where necessary, implementing acts in accordance with Article 9 concerning the precision of the statistical data required.
The Commission shall be empowered to adopt, where necessary, implementing acts in accordance with Article 9 concerning the transmission of the data referred to in Article 5, including, where appropriate, the statistical tables based on those data.
The Commission shall be empowered to adopt, where necessary, implementing acts in accordance with Article 9 concerning the dissemination of statistical results in respect of the carriage of goods by road, including the structure and content of the results to be disseminated.
Dissemination of statistical results
The Commission shall be empowered to adopt, where necessary, implementing acts in accordance with Article 9 concerning the dissemination of statistical results in respect of the carriage of goods by road, including the structure and content of the results to be disseminated.
The Commission shall be empowered to adopt, where necessary, implementing acts in accordance with Article 9 concerning the dissemination of statistical results in respect of the carriage of goods by road, including the structure and content of the results to be disseminated.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 23 February 2012.

Summary 164:
Service of documents in civil or commercial matters (Service of documents)
Service of documents in civil or commercial matters (Service of documents)
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the rules for the service of judicial and extra-judicial documents in civil and commercial matters between EU countries.
It repeals Regulation (EC) No 1348/2000.
KEY POINTS
Service of documents
The regulation applies where a judicial or extra-judicial document has to be transmitted from one EU country to another for service there.
The document must be accompanied by a standard form.
The form must be completed in the official language of the EU country addressed or in another language that country accepts.
The document and any accompanying papers must be exempt from legalisation or any equivalent formalities.
When the transmitting agency wishes a copy of the document to be returned together with the certificate, it must send the document in duplicate.
The applicant must be advised by the transmitting agency to which he forwards the document for transmission that the addressee may refuse to accept it if it is not in one of the languages provided for in the regulation.
The applicant must bear any costs of translation prior to the transmission of the document, without prejudice to any possible subsequent decision by the court or competent authority on liability for such costs.
The receiving agency must, as soon as possible and in any event within 7 days of receipt, send a receipt to the transmitting agency by the swiftest possible means of transmission using the standard form.
Where the request for service cannot be fulfilled on the basis of the information or documents transmitted, the receiving agency must contact the transmitting agency by the swiftest possible means in order to secure the missing information or documents.
If the request for service is manifestly outside the scope of the regulation or if non-compliance with the formal conditions required makes service impossible, the request and the documents transmitted must be returned, on receipt, to the transmitting agency, together with the notice of return using the standard form.
A receiving agency receiving a document for service but not having territorial jurisdiction to serve it must forward it, as well as the request, to the receiving agency having territorial jurisdiction in the same EU country if the request complies with the conditions laid down in the regulation and must inform the transmitting agency accordingly using the standard form. That receiving agency must inform the transmitting agency when it receives the document, in the manner provided for in the regulation.
The receiving agency must itself serve the document or have it served, either in accordance with the law of the EU country addressed or by a particular method requested by the transmitting agency, unless that method is incompatible with the law of that EU country.
The receiving agency must take all necessary steps to effect the service of the document as soon as possible, and in any event within 1 month of receipt. If it has not been possible to effect service within 1 month of receipt, the receiving agency must:
immediately inform the transmitting agency by means of the certificate in the standard form;
continue to take all necessary steps to effect the service of the document, unless indicated otherwise by the transmitting agency, where service seems to be possible within a reasonable period of time.
The receiving agency must inform the addressee, using the standard form, that he may refuse to accept the document to be served at the time of service or by returning the document to the receiving agency within 1 week if it is not written in, or accompanied by a translation into, either of the following languages:
a language which the addressee understands; or
the official language of the EU country addressed or, if there are several official languages in that EU country, the official language or one of the official languages of the place where service is to be effected.
If the receiving agency is informed that the addressee refuses to accept the document in accordance with the regulation, it must immediately inform the transmitting agency by means of the certificate provided for in the regulation and return the request and the documents of which a translation is requested.
If the addressee has refused to accept the document pursuant to the regulation, the service of the document can be remedied through the service on the addressee in accordance with the provisions of the regulation of the document accompanied by a translation into a language provided for in the regulation.
The date of service of the document must be the date on which the document accompanied by the translation is served in accordance with the law of the EU country addressed. However, where according to the law of an EU country, a document has to be served within a particular period, the date to be taken into account with respect to the applicant must be the date of the service of the initial document determined pursuant to the regulation.
The date of service of a document must be the date on which it is served in accordance with the law of the EU country addressed.
However, where according to the law of an EU country a document has to be served within a particular period, the date to be taken into account with respect to the applicant must be the date determined by the law of that EU country.
The certificate of service and a copy of the document served must be drawn up using the standard form.
The service of judicial documents coming from an EU country must not give rise to any payment or reimbursement of taxes or costs for services rendered by the EU country addressed.
However, the applicant must pay or reimburse the costs occasioned by:
recourse to a judicial officer or to a person competent under the law of the EU country addressed;
the use of a particular method of service.
Costs occasioned by recourse to a judicial officer or to a person competent under the law of the EU country addressed must correspond to a single fixed fee laid down by that EU country in advance which respects the principles of proportionality and non-discrimination.
Extrajudicial documents may be transmitted for service in another EU country in accordance with the provisions of the regulation.
Transmitting and receiving agencies
Each EU country must designate the public officers, authorities or other persons competent for the transmission of judicial or extrajudicial documents to be served in another EU country.
Each EU country must designate the public officers, authorities or other persons competent for the receipt of judicial or extrajudicial documents from another EU country.
A country may designate one transmitting agency and one receiving agency, or one agency to perform both functions. A federal State, a State in which several legal systems apply or a State with autonomous territorial units must be free to designate more than one such agency. The designation must have effect for a period of 5 years and may be renewed at 5-year intervals.
Each EU country must provide the Commission with the following information:
the names and addresses of the receiving agencies referred to in the regulation;
the geographical areas in which they have jurisdiction;
the means of receipt of documents available to them; and
the languages that may be used for the completion of the standard form.
The EU country must notify the Commission of any subsequent modification of such information.
Each EU country must designate a central body responsible for:
supplying information to the transmitting agencies;
seeking solutions to any difficulties which may arise during transmission of documents for service;
forwarding, in exceptional cases, at the request of a transmitting agency, a request for service to the competent receiving agency.
A federal State, a State in which several legal systems apply or a State with autonomous territorial units must be free to designate more than one central body



Summary 165:
Advanced therapy medicinal products
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EC) No 1394/2007 on advanced therapy medicinal products
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It lays down specific rules for the authorisation, supervision and pharmacovigilance of advanced therapy medicinal products (ATMPs).
It amends Directive 2001/83/EC and Regulation (EC) No 726/2007.
KEY POINTS
Advanced therapy medicinal products (ATMPs)
ATMPs are defined as:
a gene therapy medicinal product;
a somatic cell therapy medicinal product;
a tissue engineered product.
An ATMP contains or consists of engineered cells or tissues and is presented as having properties for, or is used in or administered to human beings with a view to regenerating, repairing or replacing a human tissue.
A tissue engineered product may contain cells or tissues of human or animal origin, or both. The cells or tissues may be viable or non-viable. It may also contain additional substances, such as cellular products, biomolecules, biomaterials, chemical substances, scaffolds or matrices.
Products containing or consisting exclusively of non-viable human or animal cells and/or tissues, which do not contain any viable cells or tissues and which do not act principally by pharmacological, immunological or metabolic action, shall be excluded from this definition.
Manufacturing
The Commission shall draw up guidelines on good manufacturing practice (GMP) specific to ATMPs.
Clinical trials
The rules laid down in Directive 2001/83/EC in respect of gene therapy and somatic cell therapy medicinal products shall apply to tissue engineered products.
Traceability
The holder of a marketing authorisation for an ATMP shall establish and maintain a system ensuring that the individual product and its starting and raw materials, including all substances coming into contact with the cells or tissues it may contain, can be traced through the sourcing, manufacturing, packaging, storage, transport and delivery to the hospital, institution or private practice where the product is used.
The hospital, institution or private practice where the ATMP is used shall establish and maintain a system for patient and product traceability. That system shall contain sufficient detail to allow linking of each product to the patient who received it and vice versa.
Where an ATMP contains human cells or tissues, the marketing authorisation holder, as well as the hospital, institution or private practice where the product is used, shall ensure that the traceability systems established in accordance with the regulation are complementary to, and compatible with, the requirements laid down in Directive 2004/23/EC as regards human cells and tissues other than blood cells, and in Directive 2002/98/EC as regards human blood cells.
The marketing authorisation holder shall keep the data referred to in the regulation for a minimum of 30 years after the expiry date of the product, or longer if required by the Commission as a term of the marketing authorisation.
Certification of data
The Commission shall draw up guidelines on the certification of data on the quality and safety of ATMPs.
Evaluation procedure
The Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use (CHMP) shall consult the Committee for Advanced Therapies (CAT) on any scientific assessment of ATMPs necessary to draw up the scientific opinions referred to in Article 5(2) and (3) of Regulation (EC) No 726/2004. The CAT shall also be consulted in the event of re-examination of the opinion pursuant to Article 9(2) of Regulation (EC) No 726/2004.
When preparing a draft opinion for final approval by the CHMP, the CAT shall endeavour to reach a scientific consensus. If such consensus cannot be reached, the CAT shall adopt the position of the majority of its members. The draft opinion shall mention the divergent positions and the grounds on which they are based.
The draft opinion given by the CAT under paragraph 1 shall be sent to the Chairman of the CHMP in a timely manner so as to ensure that the deadline laid down in Article 6(3) or Article 9(2) of Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 can be met.
Post-authorisation follow-up
In addition to the requirements for pharmacovigilance laid down in Articles 21 to 29 of Regulation (EC) No 726/2004, the applicant shall detail, in the marketing authorisation application, the measures envisaged to ensure the follow-up of efficacy of ATMPs and of adverse reactions thereto.
The Commission shall, on the advice of the European Medicines Agency (EMA), require as part of the marketing authorisation that a risk management system designed to identify, characterise, prevent or minimise risks related to ATMPs, including an evaluation of the effectiveness of that system, be set up, or that specific post-marketing studies be carried out by the holder of the marketing authorisation and submitted for review to the EMA.
Evaluation of the effectiveness of any risk management system and the results of any studies performed shall be included in the periodic safety update reports referred to in Article 24(3) of Regulation (EC) No 726/2004.
The EMA shall forthwith inform the Commission if it finds that the marketing authorisation holder has failed to comply with the requirements referred to in paragraph 2.
Scientific advice
The applicant or holder of a marketing authorisation may request advice from the EMA on the design and conduct of pharmacovigilance and of the risk management system referred to in Article 14.
A 90 % reduction for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and 65 % for other applicants shall apply to the fee for scientific advice payable to the EMA for any advice given in respect of ATMPs pursuant to paragraph 1 of this Article and Article 57(1)(n) of Regulation (EC) No 726/2004.
Scientific recommendation on advanced therapy classification
Any applicant developing a product based on genes, cells or tissues may request a scientific recommendation of the EMA with a view to determining whether the referred product falls, on scientific grounds, within the definition of an ATMP. The EMA shall deliver this recommendation after consultation with the Commission and within 60 days after receipt of the request.
The EMA shall publish summaries of the recommendations delivered in accordance with paragraph 1, after deletion of all information of commercial confidential nature.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 12 July 2008. It had to apply from 12 July 2008 at the latest.
BACKGROUND
              
For further information, please see ‘Advanced therapy medicinal products: what are they?’ on the European Commission’s website.
KEY TERMS
              
Advanced therapy medicinal product (ATMP): a product that:
contains or consists of engineered cells or tissues,
is presented as having properties for, or is used in or administered to human beings with a view to regenerating, repairing or replacing a human tissue.
REFERENCES
              
Regulation (EC) No 1394/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 November 2007 on advanced therapy medicinal products and amending Directive 2001/83/EC and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 (OJ L 324, 10.12.2007, pp. 121-132



Summary 166:
type-approval regulation (Euro 5 and Euro 6) and access to vehicle repair and maintenance information
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 on type-approval of motor vehicles with respect to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 5 and Euro 6) and on access to vehicle repair and maintenance information
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes common technical requirements for the type approval of motor vehicles and replacement parts, such as replacement pollution control devices, with regard to their emissions.
It lays down rules for in-service conformity, durability of pollution control devices, on-board diagnostic (OBD) systems, measurement of fuel consumption and accessibility of vehicle repair and maintenance information.
It sets out the requirements and tests for the implementation of these rules.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to vehicles of categories M1, M2, N1 and N2 as defined in Annex II to Directive 70/156/EEC with a reference mass not exceeding 2 610 kg.
At the manufacturer's request, type approval granted under this Regulation may be extended from vehicles covered by this Article to M1, M2, N1 and N2 vehicles as defined in Annex II to Directive 70/156/EEC with a reference mass not exceeding 2 840 kg and which meet the conditions laid down in this Regulation and its implementing measures.
Manufacturers’ obligations
Manufacturers must ensure that all new vehicles sold, registered or put into service in the European Union are type approved in accordance with this Regulation and its implementing measures. They must also demonstrate that all new replacement pollution control devices requiring type approval which are sold or put into service in the EU are type approved in accordance with this Regulation and its implementing measures.
Manufacturers must also ensure that type approval procedures for verifying conformity of production, durability of pollution control devices and in-service conformity are met.
Manufacturers must set out carbon dioxide emissions and fuel consumption figures in a document given to the purchaser of the vehicle at the time of purchase.
The specific procedures and requirements for the implementation of these obligations shall be established in accordance with the procedure referred to in Article 15(2).
Access to vehicle repair and maintenance information
Manufacturers must provide unrestricted and standardised access to vehicle repair and maintenance information to independent operators through websites using a standardised format in a readily accessible and prompt manner, and in a manner which is non-discriminatory compared to the provision given or access granted to authorised dealers and repairers.
Access to vehicle repair and maintenance information must include:
an unequivocal vehicle identification;
service handbooks;
technical manuals;
component and diagnosis information;
wiring diagrams;
diagnostic trouble codes;
the software calibration identification number applicable to a vehicle type;
information provided concerning, and delivered by means of, proprietary tools and equipment;
data record information and two-directional monitoring and test data.
Authorised dealers or repairers within the distribution system of a given vehicle manufacturer shall be regarded as independent operators for the purposes of this Regulation to the extent that they provide repair or maintenance services for vehicles in respect of which they are not members of the vehicle manufacturer's distribution system.
The vehicle repair and maintenance information shall always be available, except as required for maintenance purposes of the information system.
Manufacturers may charge reasonable and proportionate fees for access to vehicle repair and maintenance information covered by this Regulation; a fee is not reasonable or proportionate if it discourages access by failing to take into account the extent to which the independent operator uses it.
The measures necessary for implementation of Articles 6 and 7, which are designed to amend non-essential elements of this Regulation, by supplementing it, shall be adopted in accordance with the regulatory procedure with scrutiny referred to in Article 15(3). This shall include the definition and updating of technical specifications relating to the way in which OBD and vehicle repair and maintenance information shall be provided, with special attention being paid to the specific needs of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).
The vehicle repair and maintenance information shall always be available, except as required for maintenance purposes of the information system.
With effect from 2 July 2007, if a manufacturer so requests, the national authorities may not, on grounds relating to emissions or fuel consumption of vehicles, refuse to grant EC type approval or national type approval for a new type of vehicle, where the vehicle concerned complies with this Regulation and its implementing measures, and in particular with the Euro 5 limit values set out in Table 1 of Annex I or with the Euro 6 limit values set out in Table 2 of Annex I.
With effect from 1 September 2009, and from 1 September 2010 in the case of category N1 class II and III and category N2 vehicles, the national authorities shall refuse, on grounds relating to emissions or fuel consumption, to grant EC type approval or national type approval for new types of vehicle which do not comply with this Regulation and its implementing measures, and in particular with the Annexes, with the exception of the Euro 6 limit values set out in Table 2 of Annex I. For the test on tailpipe emissions, the limit values applied to vehicles designed to fulfil specific social needs shall be the same as for category N1 class III vehicles.
With effect from 1 January 2011, and from 1 January 2012 in the case of category N1 class II and III and category N2 vehicles and vehicles designed to fulfil specific social needs, national authorities shall, in the case of new vehicles which do not comply with this Regulation and its implementing measures, and in particular with the Annexes with the exception of the Euro 6 limit values set out in Table 2 of Annex I, consider certificates of conformity to be no longer valid for the purposes of Article 7(1) of Directive 70/156/EEC and shall, on grounds relating to emissions or fuel consumption, prohibit the registration, sale or entry into service of such vehicles. For the test on tailpipe emissions, the limit values applied to vehicles designed to fulfil specific social needs shall be the same as for category N1 class III vehicles.
With effect from 1 September 2014, and from 1 September 2015 in the case of category N1 class II and III and category N2 vehicles, the national authorities shall refuse, on grounds relating to emissions or fuel consumption, to grant EC type approval or national type approval for new types of vehicle which do not comply with this Regulation and its implementing measures, and in particular with the Euro 6 limit values set out in Table 2 of Annex I.
With effect from 1 September 2015, and from 1 September 2016 in the case of category N1 class II and III and category N2 vehicles, national authorities shall, in the case of new vehicles which do not comply with this Regulation and its implementing measures, and in particular with the Euro 6 limit values set out in Table 2 of Annex I, consider certificates of conformity to be no longer valid for the purposes of Article 7(1) of Directive 70/156/EEC and shall, on grounds relating to emissions or fuel consumption, prohibit the registration, sale or entry into service of such vehicles.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
The regulation applies from 2 July 2007.
REFERENCES

Summary 167:
common procedure for food additives, enzymes and flavourings
SUMMARY
SUMMARY
The European Parliament and the Council have established a common authorisation procedure for food additives, enzymes and flavourings. This procedure is laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1331/2008.
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes a common authorisation procedure for food additives, enzymes and flavourings in order to ensure the free movement of food within the European Union (EU) and a high level of protection of human health.
KEY POINTS
The common authorisation procedure comprises four main stages:
1.
the applicant sends the application to the European Commission;
2.
the Commission sends the application to the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA);
3.
the Commission adopts a regulation implementing the update of the Community list of authorised substances;
4.
the Commission may decide not to proceed with a planned update.
The procedure may be started either on the initiative of the Commission or following an application. Applications may be made by a Member State or by an interested party, who may represent several interested parties. Applications shall be sent to the Commission.
The Commission shall seek the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), to be given in accordance with the procedure set out in the regulation. However, for the updates referred to in Article 2(2)(b) and (c) of the regulation, the Commission shall not be required to seek the opinion of the Authority if the updates in question are not liable to have an effect on human health.
The Commission shall submit to the Committee referred to in Article 14(1) of the regulation a draft regulation updating the Community list of authorised substances. The measures, designed to amend non-essential elements of the legislation on food additives, food enzymes and flavourings, relating to the removal of a substance from the Community list, shall be adopted in accordance with the regulatory procedure with scrutiny referred to in Article 14(3) of the regulation.
On grounds of efficiency, the normal time-limits for the regulatory procedure with scrutiny may be curtailed for the addition of substances to the Community lists and for adding, removing or changing conditions, specifications or restrictions associated with the presence of a substance on the Community lists.
The Commission shall submit to the Committee referred to in Article 14(1) of the regulation a draft regulation updating the Community list of authorised substances, taking account of the opinion of the Authority, any relevant provisions of EU law and any other legitimate factors relevant to the matter under consideration.
The regulation may be amended by the Commission by means of implementing measures in accordance with the regulatory procedure referred to in Article 14(2) of the regulation.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It entered into force on 20 January 2009.

Summary 168:
Regulation on accreditation and market surveillance
REGULATION (EC) No 765/2008 sets out the rules for accreditation and market surveillance in relation to the marketing of products.
Accreditation
Accreditation is a system of attestation by a national accreditation body that a conformity assessment body meets the requirements set by harmonised standards and, where applicable, any additional requirements including those set out in relevant sectoral schemes, to carry out a specific conformity assessment activity.
Accreditation is used on a compulsory or voluntary basis, whether that assessment is compulsory or not, and irrespective of the legal status of the body performing the accreditation.
Each Member State shall appoint a single national accreditation body.
Where a Member State considers that it is not economically meaningful or sustainable to have a national accreditation body or to provide certain accreditation services, it shall, as far as possible, have recourse to the national accreditation body of another Member State.
A Member State shall inform the Commission and the other Member States where, in accordance with the above, recourse is had to the national accreditation body of another Member State.
Where accreditation is not operated directly by the public authorities themselves, a Member State shall entrust its national accreditation body with the operation of accreditation as a public authority activity and grant it formal recognition.
The responsibilities and tasks of the national accreditation body shall be clearly distinguished from those of other national authorities.
The national accreditation body shall operate on a not-for-profit basis.
The national accreditation body shall not offer or provide any activities or services that conformity assessment bodies provide, nor shall it provide consultancy services, own shares in or otherwise have a financial or managerial interest in a conformity assessment body.
Each Member State shall ensure that its national accreditation body has the appropriate financial and personnel resources for the proper performance of its tasks, including the fulfilment of special tasks, such as activities for European and international accreditation cooperation and activities that are required to support public policy and which are not self-financing.
The national accreditation body shall be a member of the body recognised under Article 14.
National accreditation bodies shall establish and maintain appropriate structures to ensure the effective and balanced involvement of all interested parties within both their organisations and the body recognised under Article 14.
A national accreditation body shall, when requested by a conformity assessment body, evaluate whether that conformity assessment body is competent to carry out a specific conformity assessment activity. Where it is found to be competent, the national accreditation body shall issue an accreditation certificate to that effect.
Where a national accreditation body ascertains that a conformity assessment body which has received an accreditation certificate is no longer competent to carry out a specific conformity assessment activity or has committed a serious breach of its obligations, that accreditation body shall take all appropriate measures within a reasonable timeframe to restrict, suspend or withdraw the accreditation certificate.
Member States shall establish procedures for the resolution of appeals, including, where appropriate, legal remedies against accreditation decisions or the absence thereof.
National accreditation bodies shall not compete with conformity assessment bodies.
National accreditation bodies shall not compete with other national accreditation bodies.
National accreditation bodies shall be permitted to operate across national borders, within the territory of another Member State, either at the request of a conformity assessment body in the circumstances set out in Article 7(1), or, if they are asked to do so by a national accreditation body in accordance with Article 7(3), in cooperation with the national accreditation body of that Member State.
Where a conformity assessment body requests accreditation it shall do so with the national accreditation body of the Member State in which it is established or with the national accreditation body to which that Member State has had recourse in accordance with Article 4(2).
A national accreditation body may request another national accreditation body to carry out part of the assessment activity. In such a case, the accreditation certificate shall be issued by the requesting body.
A national accreditation body shall fulfil the following requirements:
it shall be organised in such a manner as to make it independent of the conformity assessment bodies it assesses and of commercial pressures, and to ensure that no conflicts of interest with conformity assessment bodies occur;
it shall be organised and operated so as to safeguard the objectivity and impartiality of its activities;
it shall ensure that each decision relating to the attestation of competence is taken by competent persons different from those who carried out the assessment;
it shall have adequate arrangements to safeguard the confidentiality of the information obtained;
it shall identify the conformity assessment activities for which it is competent to perform accreditation, referring, where appropriate, to relevant Community or national legislation and standards;
it shall set up the procedures necessary to ensure efficient management and appropriate internal controls;
it shall have a number of competent personnel at its disposal sufficient for the proper performance of its tasks;
it shall document the duties, responsibilities and authorities of personnel who could affect the quality of the assessment and of the attestation of competence;
it shall establish, implement and maintain procedures for monitoring the performance and competence of the personnel involved;
it shall verify that conformity assessments are carried out in an appropriate manner, meaning that unnecessary burdens are not imposed on undertakings and that due account is taken of the size of an undertaking, the sector in which it operates, its structure, the degree of complexity of the product technology in question and the mass or serial nature of the production process;
it shall publish audited annual accounts prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
The European cooperation for Accreditation (the EA)
The European cooperation for Accreditation (the EA) is the first body recognised under this Regulation and Member States shall ensure that their national accreditation bodies seek and maintain membership of the EA for as long as it is so recognised.
The EA manages a peer evaluation system among national accreditation bodies from the Member States and other European countries. That system has proved to be efficient and to provide mutual confidence.
The EA shall:
develop and maintain a peer evaluation system for the purpose of assessing and monitoring the competence of national accreditation bodies;
organise, develop and maintain sectoral accreditation schemes;
develop and maintain a register of accredited conformity assessment bodies;
develop and maintain a register of national accreditation bodies;
develop and maintain a register of conformity assessment bodies;
develop and maintain a register of sectoral accreditation schemes;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 14;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 15;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 16;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 17;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 18;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 19;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 20;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 21;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 22;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 23;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 24;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 25;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 26;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 27;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 28;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 29;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 30;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 31;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 32;
develop and maintain a register of bodies recognised under Article 33;
develop and maintain a register

Summary 170:
Rail passengers’ rights and obligations
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EC) No 1371/2007 on rail passengers’ rights and obligations
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to strengthen passengers’ rights in the EU rail transport sector. It sets out a common set of rules for the rights and obligations of passengers and railway undertakings.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to all rail journeys and services throughout the EU provided by one or more railway undertakings licensed in accordance with Directive 95/18/EC (see summary).
It does not apply to railway undertakings and transport services which are not licensed under that Directive.
It applies to all rail passenger services throughout the EU, except for urban, suburban and regional rail passenger services, unless an exemption has been granted by a Member State.
A Member State may grant an exemption for a maximum period of 5 years for domestic rail passenger services or particular services or journeys because a significant part of the rail passenger service, including at least one scheduled station stop, is operated outside the EU.
The regulation does not apply to railway undertakings and transport services which are not licensed under Directive 95/18/EC.
Information and tickets
Railway undertakings and ticket vendors offering transport contracts on behalf of one or more railway undertakings must provide the passenger, upon request, with at least the information set out in Annex II, Part I in relation to the journeys for which a transport contract is offered by the railway undertaking concerned.
Ticket vendors offering transport contracts on their own account, and tour operators, must provide this information where available.
During the journey, railway undertakings must provide the passenger with at least the information set out in Annex II, Part II.
Railway undertakings and ticket vendors must offer, where available, tickets, through tickets and reservations.
Liability for passengers and luggage
The liability of railway undertakings in respect of passengers and their luggage is governed by Chapters I, III and IV of Title IV, Title VI and Title VII of Annex I.
The obligation set out in Article 9 of Directive 95/18/EC as far as it relates to liability for passengers shall be understood as requiring a railway undertaking to be adequately insured or to make equivalent arrangements for cover of its liabilities under this Regulation.
Delays, missed connections and cancellations
The liability of railway undertakings in respect of delays, missed connections and cancellations is governed by Chapter II of Title IV of Annex I.
Where it is reasonably to be expected that the delay in the arrival at the final destination under the transport contract will be more than 60 minutes, the passenger shall immediately have the choice between:
reimbursement of the full cost of the ticket, under the conditions by which it was paid, for the part or parts of his or her journey not made and for the part or parts already made if the journey is no longer serving any purpose in relation to the passenger’s original travel plan, together with, when relevant, a return service to the first point of departure at the earliest opportunity;
continuation or re-routing, under comparable transport conditions, to the final destination at the earliest opportunity; or
continuation or re-routing, under comparable transport conditions, to the final destination at a later date at the passenger’s convenience.
Compensation for delays
Without losing the right of transport, a passenger may request compensation for delays from the railway undertaking if he or she is facing a delay between the places of departure and destination stated on the ticket for which the ticket has not been reimbursed in accordance with Article 16. The minimum compensations for delays shall be as follows:
25 % of the ticket price for a delay of 60 to 119 minutes;
50 % of the ticket price for a delay of 120 minutes or more.
Passengers who hold a travel pass or season ticket and who encounter recurrent delays or cancellations during its period of validity may request adequate compensation in accordance with the railway undertaking’s compensation arrangements. These arrangements shall state the criteria for determining delay and for the calculation of the compensation.
Disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility
Railway undertakings and station managers shall, with the active involvement of representative organisations of disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility, establish, or shall have in place, non-discriminatory access rules for the transport of disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility.
Reservations and tickets shall be offered to disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility at no additional cost. A railway undertaking, ticket vendor or tour operator may not refuse to accept a reservation from, or issue a ticket to, a disabled person or a person with reduced mobility, or require that such person be accompanied by another person, unless this is strictly necessary in order to comply with the access rules referred to in the first paragraph.
Upon request, a railway undertaking, a ticket vendor or a tour operator shall provide disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility with information on the accessibility of rail services and on the access conditions of rolling stock in accordance with the access rules referred to in the first paragraph and shall inform disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility about facilities on board.
Railway undertakings, station managers, ticket vendors and tour operators shall cooperate in order to provide assistance to disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility in line with Articles 22 and 23 in accordance with the following points:
assistance shall be provided on condition that the railway undertaking, the station manager, the ticket vendor or the tour operator with which the ticket was purchased is notified of the person’s disability or reduced mobility;
the railway undertaking, the station manager, the ticket vendor or the tour operator shall accept a written declaration from the passenger that he or she is disabled or has reduced mobility;
the railway undertaking, the station manager, the ticket vendor or the tour operator shall accept a certificate issued by a doctor or other appropriate health professional, which is no more than 12 months old, that the passenger is disabled or has reduced mobility;
the railway undertaking, the station manager, the ticket vendor or the tour operator shall accept a certificate issued by a doctor or other appropriate health professional, which is no more than 12 months old, that the passenger is disabled or has reduced mobility and that the facilities or services requested are necessary for the person’s disability or reduced mobility.
Assistance for disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility
On departure from, transit through or arrival at, a staffed railway station of a disabled person or a person with reduced mobility, the station manager shall provide assistance free of charge in such a way that that person is able to board the departing service, or to disembark from the arriving service for which he or she purchased a ticket.
In unstaffed stations, railway undertakings and station managers shall ensure that easily accessible information is displayed in accordance with the access rules regarding the nearest staffed stations and directly available assistance for disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility.
Railway undertakings shall provide disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility assistance free of charge on board a train and during boarding and disembarking from a train.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
The regulation applies from 12 December 2009.
REFERENCES
              
Regulation (EC) No 1371/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 October 2007 on rail passengers’ rights and obligations (OJ L 318, 24.12



Summary 171:
EU statistics on education and lifelong learning
EU statistics on education and lifelong learning
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It sets out the rules for the production and development of statistics on education and lifelong learning in the European Union (EU).
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to the production of statistics in three domains:
Domain 1: education and training systems;
Domain 2: participation of adults in lifelong learning;
Domain 3: other statistics on education and lifelong learning.
The annex to the regulation specifies the scope of each of these domains.
Production of statistics
The production of Community statistics in the field of education and lifelong learning is implemented by individual statistical actions. These include:
the regular delivery of statistics on education and lifelong learning by the EU Member States;
the use of other statistical information systems and surveys, to provide additional statistical variables and indicators on education and lifelong learning;
the development, improvement and updating of standards and manuals on statistical frameworks, concepts and methods;
the improvement of data quality, in the context of the quality framework.
Transmission of micro-data on individuals
When necessary for the production of Community statistics, EU Member States may transmit confidential micro-data resulting from sample surveys to the European Commission (Eurostat). The transmitted data must not permit the direct identification of the statistical units (individuals).
Implementing measures
The Commission (Eurostat) adopts implementing measures to:
select and specify the subjects covered by the domains and their characteristics in response to policy or technical needs;
breakdown the characteristics;
set the observation period and deadlines for transmission of results;
set the quality requirements, including the required precision;
set the quality reporting framework.
The Commission (Eurostat) may also adopt implementing measures to:
take account of the potential burden on educational institutions and individuals;
take account of the results of pilot studies;
take account of the latest agreements between the UNESCO Institute for Statistics, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and the Commission (Eurostat) on concepts, definitions, data collection format, data processing, periodicity and deadlines for transmission of results;
take account of the results from the Adult Education Pilot Survey performed between 2005 and 2007 and further development needs;
take account of the availability, suitability and the legal context of existing Community data sources.
Committee
The Commission (Eurostat) is assisted by the Statistical Programme Committee.
Implementing measures are adopted in accordance with the regulatory procedure with scrutiny.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 7 June 2008.

Summary 172:
EU statistics on energy supply and consumption
EU statistics on energy supply and consumption
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes a common framework for the production, transmission, evaluation and dissemination of comparable energy statistics in the EU.
KEY POINTS
The regulation covers statistical data on all types of energy products and their aggregates in the EU.
The EU countries must collect data from specific statistical surveys addressed to the primary and transformed energy producers and traders, importers and exporters, as well as other statistical surveys addressed to final energy users.
The EU countries must lay down the detailed rules concerning the reporting of the data needed for the national statistics as specified in Annexes B, C and D by undertakings and other sources.
The regulation applies to all EU countries except Denmark which has opted out of this regulation.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It has applied since 1 January 2009.

Summary 173:
Passenger rights in bus and coach transport
Passenger rights in bus and coach transport
SUMMARY OF REGULATION (EU) No 181/2011
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
              
It lays down rules for passengers in bus and coach transport.
KEY POINTS
              
The regulation applies to passengers travelling with regular services for non-specified categories of passengers where the boarding or the alighting point of the passengers is situated in the territory of a Member State and where the scheduled distance of the service is 250 km or more.
It establishes rights for passengers in the event of accidents arising out of the use of the bus or coach resulting in death or personal injury or loss of or damage to luggage.
It establishes non-discrimination and mandatory assistance for disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility.
It establishes rights for passengers in cases of cancellation or delay.
It establishes minimum information to be provided to passengers.
It establishes procedures for handling complaints.
It establishes general rules on enforcement.
The regulation does not apply to passengers travelling with occasional services where the initial boarding point or the final alighting point of the passenger is situated in the territory of a Member State.
The regulation does not apply to passengers travelling with domestic regular services which have been exempted by a Member State for a maximum period of 4 years from the date of application of the regulation.
The regulation does not apply to passengers travelling with particular regular services because a significant part of such regular services, including at least one scheduled stop, is operated outside the Union. Such exemptions may be granted for a maximum period of 4 years from the date of application of the regulation.
The regulation does not affect the rights of passengers under Directive 90/314/EEC and does not apply in case where a package tour referred to in that Directive is cancelled for reasons other than cancellation of a regular service.
KEY TERMS
              
Regular services: services which provide for the carriage of passengers by bus or coach at specified intervals along specified routes, passengers being picked up and set down at predetermined stopping points.
Occasional services: services which do not fall within the definition of regular services and the main characteristic of which is the carriage by bus or coach of groups of passengers constituted on the initiative of the customer or the carrier himself.
Carrier: a natural or legal person, other than a tour operator, travel agent or ticket vendor, offering transport by regular or occasional services to the general public.
Performing carrier: a natural or legal person other than the carrier, who actually performs the carriage wholly or partially.
Ticket vendor: any intermediary concluding transport contracts on behalf of a carrier.
Travel agent: any intermediary acting on behalf of a passenger for the conclusion of transport contracts.
Tour operator: an organiser or retailer, other than the carrier, within the meaning of Article 2(2) and (3) of Directive 90/314/EEC.
Disabled person or person with reduced mobility: any person whose mobility when using transport is reduced as a result of any physical disability (sensory or locomotory, permanent or temporary), intellectual disability or impairment, or any other cause of disability, or as a result of age, and whose situation needs appropriate attention and adaptation to his particular needs of the services made available to all passengers.
Access conditions: relevant standards, guidelines and information on the accessibility of buses and/or of designated terminals including their facilities for disabled persons or persons with reduced mobility.
Terminal: a staffed terminal where according to the specified route a regular service is scheduled to stop for passengers to board or alight, equipped with facilities such as a check-in counter, waiting room or ticket office.
Bus stop: any point other than a terminal where according to the specified route a regular service is scheduled to stop for passengers to board or alight.
Terminal managing body: an organisational entity in a Member State responsible for the management of a designated terminal.
Cancellation: the non-operation of a regular service which was previously scheduled.
Delay: a difference between the time the regular service was scheduled to depart in accordance with the published timetable and the time of its actual departure.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
The regulation applies from 1 March 2013.
