Summary 174:
EU statistics on aquaculture
EU statistics on aquaculture
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EC) No 762/2008 on the submission by Member States of statistics on aquaculture
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It sets out the rules for the collection of statistics on the production and structure of the European Union’s (EU) aquaculture sector.
KEY POINTS
The EU’s aquaculture sector is a major contributor to the EU’s fisheries production. It is expected to continue to grow in the coming years, providing the EU with a large share of its fish consumption. It is therefore essential that the sector is properly monitored and managed.
The regulation sets out the rules for the collection of statistics on the production and structure of the EU’s aquaculture sector. The data are collected from national authorities responsible for the sector and submitted to the European Commission (Eurostat) on an annual basis.
Production
The regulation covers the following:
the annual production (volume and unit value) of aquaculture;
the annual input (volume and unit value) to capture-based aquaculture;
the annual production of hatcheries and nurseries;
the structure of the aquaculture sector.
The regulation covers the whole of the EU’s territory, including territorial waters, and inland waters such as lakes and rivers.
The data are collected from national authorities responsible for the sector and submitted to the Commission (Eurostat) on an annual basis. The first reference calendar year is 2008. The data are submitted within 12 months of the end of the reference calendar year.
The Commission (Eurostat) publishes the statistics in its online database.
Structure
The regulation also covers the structure of the sector. The data are collected from national authorities responsible for the sector and submitted to the Commission (Eurostat) on an annual basis. The first reference calendar year is 2008. The data are submitted within 12 months of the end of the reference calendar year.
The Commission (Eurostat) publishes the statistics in its online database.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2009.
BACKGROUND
              
The regulation repeals Council Regulation (EC) No 788/96 on the submission by Member States of statistics on aquaculture production. That regulation required the Member States to submit annual data on the volume of production.
The increasing contribution of aquaculture to the EU’s total fisheries production requires a wider range of data for a rational development and management of this sector within the Common Fisheries Policy.
The regulation also covers the production of hatcheries and nurseries for aquaculture activity.
The regulation was adopted in 2008, following the adoption of the new Common Fisheries Policy in 2009.
For more information, see:
EU aquaculture production (Eurostat).
KEY TERMS
              
Aquaculture: the breeding, rearing and reproduction of aquatic animals and plants under controlled conditions.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2009.

Scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries — repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2791/1999
Scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries — repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2791/1999
This Regulation lays down a scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries. It also repeals Council Regulation (EC) No 2791/1999.
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to ensure that the Union applies the scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries (NEAFC).
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to all EU vessels used or intended for use for fishing activities carried out in respect of fishery resources in the Regulatory Area (the waters of the Convention Area which lie beyond the waters under the fisheries jurisdiction of the Contracting Parties).
Monitoring measures
Member States shall send to the Commission, in a computer-readable form, a list of all vessels flying their flag and registered in the Union which are authorised to fish in the Regulatory Area, in particular the vessels authorised to fish directly for one or more regulated resources.
Member States shall ensure that gear used by their fishing vessels in the Regulatory Area is marked in accordance with Commission Regulation (EC) No 356/2005.
Member States shall undertake to retrieve on a regular basis lost gears belonging to vessels flying their flag.
In addition to the information specified in Article 6 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 2847/93, the masters of EU fishing vessels shall record, either in a bound paginated fishing logbook or by electronic means, the following:
each entry into and exit from the Regulatory Area;
on a daily basis and/or for each haul the estimated cumulative catches retained on board since the last entry into the Regulatory Area;
on a daily basis and/or for each haul the amount of fish discarded;
immediately after each communication pursuant to Article 9, the date and time, according to Universal Coordinated Time (UTC), of transmission of a report and, in the case of radio transmission, the name of the radio station through which the report was transmitted;
the fishing depth, where appropriate.
In addition to the information specified in Article 6 of Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009, the masters of EU fishing vessels shall record, either in a bound paginated fishing logbook or by electronic means, the following:
each entry into and exit from the Regulatory Area;

on a daily basis and/or for each haul the amount of fish discarded;
immediately after each communication pursuant to Article 9, the date and time, according to Universal Coordinated Time (UTC), of transmission of a report and, in the case of radio transmission, the name of the radio station through which the report was transmitted;
the fishing depth, where appropriate.

Summary 176:
EU Ecolabel — a new label for the environment
EU Ecolabel — a new label for the environment
The EU Ecolabel is a voluntary eco-label for products that meet high environmental standards. It was created in 2000 by Regulation (EC) No 1980/2000. This Regulation repeals the previous one and introduces changes to the EU Ecolabel scheme.
ACT
Regulation (EC) No 66/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2009 on the EU Ecolabel.
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes a revised EU Ecolabel scheme which is intended to promote products with a reduced environmental impact during their entire life cycle and to provide consumers with accurate, non-deceptive, science-based information on the environmental impact of products.
KEY POINTS
The EU Ecolabel may be used by operators (manufacturers, importers, wholesalers, retailers) who have been awarded the EU Ecolabel and comply with the EU Ecolabel criteria and the assessment requirements published by the European Commission.
EU Ecolabel criteria
EU Ecolabel criteria shall be based on the environmental performance of products, taking into account the latest strategic objectives of the Community in the field of the environment.
EU Ecolabel criteria shall set out the environmental requirements that a product must fulfil in order to bear the EU Ecolabel.
EU Ecolabel criteria shall be determined on a scientific basis considering the whole life cycle of products.
For specific categories of goods containing substances referred to in Article 6(6) of this Regulation, the Commission may adopt measures to grant derogations from Article 6(6). No derogation shall be given concerning substances that meet the criteria of Article 57 of Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 and that are identified according to the procedure described in Article 59(1) of that Regulation, present in mixtures, in an article or in any homogeneous part of a complex article in concentrations higher than 0,1 % (weight by weight).
Development and revision of EU Ecolabel criteria
The Commission may initiate and lead the development or revision of EU Ecolabel criteria.
The Commission shall, no later than nine months after consulting the EUEB, adopt measures to establish specific EU Ecolabel criteria for each product group.
Award of the EU Ecolabel and terms and conditions of its use
The EU Ecolabel shall have the form depicted in Annex II of this Regulation.
The EU Ecolabel may only be used in connection with products complying with the EU Ecolabel criteria applicable to the products concerned and for which the EU Ecolabel has been awarded.
Applications shall specify the full contact details of the operator, as well as the product group in question and shall contain a full description of the product as well as all other information requested by the competent body.
The competent body to which an application is made shall charge fees according to Annex III of this Regulation. The use of the EU Ecolabel shall be conditional upon the fees having been paid in due time.
Market surveillance and control of the use of the EU Ecolabel
The competent body shall, in respect of products to which it has awarded the EU Ecolabel, verify that the product complies with the EU Ecolabel criteria and assessment requirements published under Article 8, on a regular basis.
The user of the EU Ecolabel shall, upon request by the competent body which has awarded the EU Ecolabel to the product, grant access to the premises on which the product concerned is produced.
The competent body which finds that a product bearing the EU Ecolabel does not comply with the relevant product group criteria or that the EU Ecolabel is not used in accordance with Article 9, shall either prohibit the use of the EU Ecolabel on that product, or, in the event that the EU Ecolabel has been awarded by another competent body, it shall inform that competent body. The user of the EU Ecolabel shall not be entitled to repayment of the fees referred to in Article 9(4), either in whole or in part.
Promotion of the EU Ecolabel
Member States and the Commission shall, in cooperation with the EUEB, agree on a specific action plan to promote the use of the EU Ecolabel by:
awareness-raising actions and information and public education campaigns for consumers, producers, manufacturers, wholesalers, service providers, public purchasers, traders, retailers and the general public,
encouraging the uptake of the scheme, especially for SMEs,
thus supporting the development of the scheme.
Promotion of the EU Ecolabel may be undertaken via the EU Ecolabel website providing basic information and promotional materials on the EU Ecolabel, and information on where to purchase EU Ecolabel products, in all Community languages.
Member States shall encourage the use of the ‘Manual for authorities awarding public contracts’, as specified in Annex I, Part A, point 5. For this purpose, Member States shall consider, for example, the setting of targets for the purchasing of products meeting the criteria specified in that Manual.
Exchange of information and experiences
Competent bodies shall regularly exchange information and experiences, in particular on the application of Articles 9 and 10.
The Commission shall set up a working group of competent bodies for this purpose. The working group shall meet at least twice a year. Travel expenses shall be borne by the Commission.
KEY TERMS
EU Ecolabel: voluntary eco-label for products that meet high environmental standards.
FROM WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 20 January 2010.

Summary 177:
EU supplementary protection certificates for medicinal products
EU supplementary protection certificates for medicinal products
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It codifies Regulation (EC) No 1768/92 which provides for supplementary protection certificates for medicinal products.
The regulation extends the duration of the patent for the product concerned by the period between the date on which the application for the patent was lodged and the date on which the first authorisation to place the medicinal product on the market was granted in the EU.
The regulation aims to encourage the development of new medicinal products.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to medicinal products which are protected by a patent and subject to an administrative authorisation procedure before being placed on the market.
The application for the certificate must be lodged within 6 months of the date on which the authorisation to place the medicinal product on the market was granted.
The certificate is granted for a period of 5 years from the date on which it takes effect.
The duration of the certificate may not exceed 5 years from the date on which it takes effect.
The certificate may be granted in the 10 new EU countries which joined the EU in 2004, 2007 and 2013.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 16 June 2009.
